Headline: Barron's(1/22) 2007 Barron's Roundtable -- Part -7-
Story: Neff: Right, 8.8%. Lord, the economy is going to grow at 2.5%. The business has got to turn around. Other truckers sell for 11-13 times earnings. YRC gets a 14% return on equity. It pays no dividend, though it could look to do so within the next 12 months. That would make it a 10% grower with a 1.5% yield, or something like that. They have economies of scale that nobody else has. They have 60% of the long-haul, less-than-truckload market, and 1,000 terminals. You import goods from abroad, and you've got to distribute them around the country.   Gabelli: Play that again, John. Why do you think a 9% decline in November was just an aberration?   Neff: I can't explain it precisely, Mario. Somebody in Massachussetts declared inventories too high, so they didn't move more stuff into the market. I only know it explains the problem with earnings. If they move more freight next year at, say, 3% or 3.5%, YRC is going to participate.   Witmer: What was the trend in trucking tonnage year-to-date through November? I'm trying to normalize the number. Maybe they shipped too much early on in the year.   Hickey: It has been dropping. It was down 4% in October, and 8.8% in November.   Faber: Year-to-date for 2006, tonnage is down 2.8% relative to 2005.   Cohen: The data from the U.S. government show a couple of interesting trends. First, a lot of the movement in the inventory-to-sales ratio has been related to the transportation sector -- that is, transportation equipment being shipped or not being shipped. That tends to move the numbers around a lot, because these are big, expensive items like airplanes. Second, the new-orders-to-shipments ratio, a more arcane number in the same release, has been moving higher and higher, so the orders are out there.     Barron's: Is that ratio just for trucking?   Cohen: No. Transportation equipment helps explain some of the lumpiness in the I/S ratio, but the unfilled orders-to-shipments data apply to the overall economy.   Neff: One of the knocks on YRC has been that it's unionized. There used to be quite a spread in wage levels between union and nonunion truckers, but it has narrowed considerably. It's hard to find truck drivers, particularly cross-country drivers. You have to pay up for them.   My last stock is an old favorite, Citigroup [C]. The stock had an overdue move last year. I was having a bad year and it bailed me out. Citi had a big meeting recently and swore that non-interest expense would rise less than revenue this year. There are all kinds of economies of scale at this company. They don't have a big branch system in the U.S., but a big hunk of the credit-card business, which is somewhat the same. Within the last few years they bought the credit-card businesses of Sears, Home Depot and Federated Department Stores. You crank all that into the existing infrastructure and you make out on the bottom line. Some people say the company should split itself up or spin off components, but then it would lose these economies of scale, including in investment banking. Their investment-banking operations are all over the world.   Cohen: Does their credit-card business have any exposure to sub-prime loans?   Neff: Very little. They are pretty careful. The stock is 54.77. I've got them earning $4.75 a share for 2007. The stock is trading for 11 times earnings, twice the multiple of my other picks. But Citi is a solid 10%-12% grower. It has 3.6% yield. They meet in a couple of weeks, and I think they'll raise the dividend from 49 cents to 54 cents a share, which would lift the yield to 4%. [Friday Citigroup announced it will indeed hike its dividend to 54 cents.]     Barron's: What are you looking for on the stock?   Neff: Long-term it should trade at a market multiple, but I would settle for 13 times earnings in the next year. Thirteen times $4.75 would be around 62. That's not super upside, but the stock could be up 11%-12%. Last year Citi was up 14.8%   The company has a double-A credit rating. It paid cash for all its acquisitions in recent years yet hasn't destroyed that rating. Just in the last three months Citi bought 20% of the most significant bank in Turkey, and 20% of a troubled bank in China. Their market capitalization is $265 billion.     Barron's: Sounds good. Thanks, John.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) Lords Of The Manor
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Robin Goldwyn Blumenthal   There was time when nursing homes were all about giving elderly people care and comfort for a number of years, often their last.   But fraud in the industry, which pushed expenses up, and changes in government Medicare reimbursements, which pushed payments down, forced many nursing companies into bankruptcy, and others to be more creative about finding new sources of revenue. Manor Care (ticker: HCR) came through the right-sizing of the industry unscathed and now falls squarely in the latter camp.   In the past 10 years, the Toledo, Ohio, company has moved aggressively from offering just long-term care to also providing intensive shorter-term rehabilitation for people recovering from strokes, heart attacks and other conditions. Indeed, the average stay at a Manor Care facility, which go under such names as Heartland and ManorCare Health Services, has shrunk to 90 days, from the two years of 20 years ago. And the shorter stays are far more profitable, commanding double the daily bed rates of conventional nursing-home care.   The company, with a stock-market value of $3.7 billion, also has a fast-growing hospice and home health-care operations, outpatient rehab therapy and assisted living facilities for patients with Alzheimer's and dementia. In all, it operates more than 500 facilities across the country, most of which it owns.   Manor Care's stock, however, hasn't kept pace with all the improvements. Though the company is an acknowledged leader, its shares, at about 50, have been changing hands at 18.5 times estimated earnings for this year -- lower than the multiples of most rivals. While the stock popped last Tuesday on excitement about a premium-priced buyout plan of a similar company, Genesis HealthCare (GHCI), it's still 6% off its 52-week high, set in August.   Jim Lane, a portfolio manager at Tripoint Asset Management, a Boston-based hedge fund, figures earnings per share are growing at 15% a year, thanks to brisk sales gains, solid operating leverage and share repurchases. And with an ample free-cash-flow yield of 4.5%, the company could boost its dividend and continue buying back shares, he says. Manor Care repurchased 14% of its stock in the past year.   "If I can buy a 15% EPS-growth company at a cash-flow yield that's in parity with the 10-year Treasury, it's pretty attractive," says Lane, whose fund has been buying shares at recent prices.   He sees the stock heading to $65 within 18 months, adding that the value of its extensive real-estate holdings should limit the downside.   There's no mystery to Manor Care's new emphasis on shorter-stay patients. While a traditional nursing-home patient might pay $200 a day, the norm for the more intensive rehab patients is closer to $400.   "Our strategy is to increase cash flow per bed," Manor Care Chairman and CEO Paul Ormond told Barron's. While 39% of Manor Care's approximately $3.6 billion in revenue comes from intensive rehab or patients needing complex medical care, Ormond sees that higher-margin work accounting for more than half the company's business in less than five years. Hospice care, now about 15%, will dominate the other half of the company, while traditional skilled nursing, now near 50%, will fall to about one-quarter of the company's revenues, Ormond figures.   With demand growing for the newer services, Manor Care looks well-positioned to keep bolstering its bottom line. Occupancy levels, at 89%, are at a 10-year high, and the company is operating efficiently. Susan Robbins, a senior analyst at longtime Manor Care investor Baron Capital Group, calls the company "a low-cost provider for post-acute rehabilitation care." The costs are especially low, compared with those of full-scale hospitals. That helps win patient referrals.   Though Manor Care doesn't need acquisitions to grow, Ormond won't rule them out. Its ownership of 97% of its real estate is "at a minimum, dry powder for us" should an opportunity present itself, he  says.   The Medicare reimbursement landscape, meanwhile, is expected to remain relatively stable, since Democrats, now the majority in Congress, have long been favorably disposed to the nursing-home industry. All of which should provide a nice backdrop for healthy growth.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) Asian Trader: Outlook Bright For Japan's Credit-Card Shares
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mayuko Ota   Credit-card issuers could be the big winners in a Japanese consumer-finance industry that has been ravaged by the recent imposition of interest-rate caps.   In Japan, consumer financing is divided broadly into two kinds of players, the consumer-loan companies and credit-card companies. The former, comparable to U.S. sub-prime lenders, offer credit to lower-middle-income families with average debt of over $10,000. In contrast, credit-card companies -- still an underdeveloped industry -- serve shoppers who make minimal use of the cards and tend to pay off card balances every month.   The system yielded high returns for consumer-loan companies. Even though some of their borrowers weren't the most creditworthy, the risks were offset by the high interest rates the lenders could charge -- up to 29%. But on Dec. 13, the government limited rates to a maximum of 18%-20%.   Consumer-finance stocks all took beatings after the rate-regulation debate began in March, with shares of loan company Acom (ticker: 8572.Tokyo) plummeting 42% and those of credit-card issuer Credit Saison (82.53.Tokyo) losing 37%. But the major card companies, with a lower-risk clientele, won't be affected nearly as badly as the consumer lenders. "I still remain bullish on high-quality card companies, despite the radical change," says Shiro Yoshiyoka, a Mizuho Securities analyst. "The consumer bases are significantly different, so credit companies should be OK." He and some other analysts strongly recommend Credit Saison and Aeon Credit (8570.Tokyo).   The new interest-rate limits are leading Citigroup (C) to close 84% of its Japanese consumer-loan operations. "Citigroup's sweeping round of restructuring is a signal of things to come," warns Takehiro Tsuda of Nikko Citigroup, the most vocal industry doomsayer. "It's highly possible two or more of the major lenders, possibly Acom [8572.Tokyo] and Aiful [8515.Tokyo], will go bankrupt."   The card outfits' better outlook is reflected in their stocks' valuations. At its recent price of 4,570 yen -- about $38 -- Credit Saison sells at about two times book value and at 17 times analysts' average earnings estimate for fiscal 2008. At its recent price of 2,330 yen, Aeon Credit's price-book ratio is 2.5; its P/E is 14.5. Consumer-finance shares, in contrast, trade barely above de facto book value.   "One advantage of Credit Saison is that they can make profit even under tight pressure," says Ayako Sato at UBS Securities. The company has a 17% market share and lots of retail allies, including the Japan Postal Service and Seibu department store. That share could grow through M&A and aggressive marketing over the next few years.   Aeon Credit has also safely positioned itself with a strong base of low-risk customers, successfully piggy-backing on its parent company's retail outlets. About a quarter of its revenue and 18% of its profit comes from outside Japan.   Credit-card shopping accounts for roughly 10% of consumption in Japan, versus close to 25% in the U.S. In fiscal 2005, purchases on plastic leapt 14%, according to the Japan Consumer Credit Industry, and they're likely to keep rising. Sato notes that cards now can be used to pay highway tolls and utility and hospital bills. In the next few years, taxes probably also will be payable with plastic.   Credit Saison and Aeon Credit look well-placed to capitalize on these changes.   ---   Mayuko Ota reports for Dow Jones Newswires from Tokyo.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Ill, Vt Demand Eli Lilly Turn Over Zyprexa Marketing Data-NYT
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Stepping up government investigations into Eli Lilly & Co.'s (LLY) marketing of its best-selling drug Zyprexa, state prosecutors in Illinois and Vermont have demanded that the company turn over information about the way it promoted the medication, the New York Times reported in its Saturday editions.   On Thursday, lawyers from the consumer protection division of the Illinois attorney general's office demanded that Lilly hand over marketing materials, email messages, and other documents with information about promotion of Zyprexa, the Times reported. Vermont investigators issued a similar order Friday morning, the report said.   The orders are the civil equivalents of criminal subpoenas, according to Deborah Hagan, the chief of the Illinois consumer protection division, the report said.   Illinois and Vermont are now part of a coordinated five-state civil investigation into the way Lilly promoted Zyprexa, a treatment for schizophrenia and bipolar disorder, the report said. The states are investigating whether Lilly tried to hide Zyprexa's risk of causing weight gain and other risks associated with diabetes and whether the company promoted Zyprexa for use in patients who do not have schizophrenia or bipolar disorder, the report said.   Federal laws prohibit such so-called "off label" marketing, although doctors may prescribe any drug for any disease that they believe the drug will help, the report said.   The orders on Thursday and Friday are the first formal demands for Lilly documents from state attorneys and they indicate an escalation of the investigation, according to Hagan and Julie Brill, who is an assistant attorney general in Vermont, the Times reported.   "We can ask for documents; we can ask for answers to questions; and we can ask for people to come in and testify under oath," Hagan said, the report said. Federal prosecutors in Philadelphia have also recently accelerated their own investigation into Lilly's marketing of Zyprexa, the report said.   In a statement Friday, Lilly said it would cooperate with the investigations and had done nothing wrong, the report said. "We intend to cooperate with the Illinois attorney general's civil investigative demand relating to Zyprexa," the company said, the Times reported. "We cannot comment further about this or other ongoing investigations," it said, according to the Times.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 02:11 ET (07:11 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: China Leader Urges Spending More Foreign Exchange Reserves
Story: BEIJING (AP)--The Chinese premier called Saturday for spending more of China's foreign exchange reserves and spreading economic growth to the country's rural areas, seeking to sustain the growth that has made China the world's fourth largest economy.   The government "must actively explore and broaden the channels and manner of using foreign exchange reserves," Premier Wen Jiabao said at the end of a two-day financial policy conference. He didn't elaborate.   China's foreign exchange reserves are the world's largest, at $1.06 trillion and growing.   How to spend the money, which is usually invested in U.S. Treasury securities and other low-risk instruments, has been hotly debated among Chinese officials. Beijing is unlikely to dump its U.S. holdings, analysts have said, because that would shock the American economy - China's top export market - and the dollar, sending the value of China's reserves plummeting.   Wen also announced that the debt-laden Agriculture Bank of China will be restructured and greater financial support given to rural China.   While many of the measures were expected, the conference, held once every five years, comes as the communist government is trying to ease friction at home over a widening gap between rich and poor and dampen criticism abroad about its trade surplus.   Wen acknowledged that it was proving a challenge to manage domestic social strains, the trade surplus - which grew 74% last year to $177.47 billion - and inflows of investment.   "We must increase the sense of urgency and responsibility in financial work," state television and the Xinhua News Agency quoted Wen as saying.   With so much money flooding in, Chinese leaders and economists are worried that the surge could touch off inflation or a binge of ill-conceived lending by banks and spending by companies. The trade surplus has also fueled criticism in the U.S. and the E.U. that China was depressing the value of its currency, the yuan, making its exports cheaper.   In recent weeks, China has accelerated the yuan's rise against the dollar, and Wen said that exchange rate adjustments will continue.   Less clear, however, was whether China intended to use its foreign exchange reserves to buy up assets abroad, helping to reduce trade tensions. In debate over how to spend the reserves, which in addition to U.S. Treasury bonds have been used to bail out state banks, some Chinese scholars have suggested buying up oil and gas fields or other strategic commodities.   Xinhua said that the trillion-dollar reserve "could buy Microsoft, Citibank and Exxon Mobil Corp. as well as General Motors and Ford."     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 11:08 ET (16:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Tribune Company Updates Strategic Review Process
Story: CHICAGO, Jan. 20 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Tribune Company (NYSE: TRB) said today that the independent special committee of its board of directors is continuing its strategic review following the submission of proposals from prospective investors.     "The committee is actively engaged in the review process," said William A. Osborn, Tribune's lead independent director and chairman of the special committee.  "Assisted by our outside legal and financial advisors, we are carefully considering all alternatives for creating additional shareholder value.  These alternatives include potential transactions involving third parties as well as actions the company may take alone."     In September, the company announced the formation of the independent special committee to oversee management's exploration of strategic alternatives for creating additional shareholder value.  The committee will make a recommendation to the full board of directors.  The board has said it expects to announce a decision during the first quarter of 2007.     TRIBUNE (NYSE: TRB) is one of the country's top media companies, operating businesses in publishing, interactive and broadcasting. It reaches more than 80 percent of U.S. households and is the only media organization with newspapers, television stations and websites in the nation's top three markets. In publishing, Tribune's leading daily newspapers include the Los Angeles Times, Chicago Tribune, Newsday (Long Island, N.Y.), The Sun (Baltimore), South Florida Sun-Sentinel, Orlando Sentinel and Hartford Courant. The company's broadcasting group operates 23 television stations, Superstation WGN on national cable, Chicago's WGN-AM and the Chicago Cubs baseball team. Popular news and information websites complement Tribune's print and broadcast properties and extend the company's nationwide audience.    SOURCE  Tribune Company       /CONTACT: MEDIA: Gary Weitman, office - +1-312-222-3394, gweitman@tribune.com; INVESTORS: Ruthellyn Musil, office - +1-312-222-3787, rmusil@tribune.com, both of Tribune Company, fax - +1-312-222-1573      /Web site: http://www.tribune.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 17:12 ET (22:12 GMT)

Headline: : ICICI Bank Announces Performance -2-
Barron's(1/22) Follow-Up: Pricing Outlook Bright For Alcoa
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Neil A. Martin   Ever since we alerted readers to an impending turnaround at Alcoa, the company's stock has plotted a roller-coaster course: plunging 19.7% to as low as 22.28 a couple of months after we wrote about it ("Alcoa's Shiny Prospects," Aug. 8, 2005) before soaring to a high near 37 last May, with many dips and surges, before and after.   Shareholders should stay buckled up for another climb, says fund manager John Buckingham of Laguna Beach, Calif.-based Al Frank Asset Management. The shares enjoyed a renewed surge Friday, rising 3.3%, to 31.31, on news of a big stock buyback and a 13% dividend hike.   Buckingham says the world's largest aluminum maker (ticker: AA) is worth buying up to 32.41. Before Friday's afternoon's jump, it was trading at 10 times estimated earnings for the year ahead, "which we believe is cheap given the likelihood of continued strong demand for aluminum products," he said.   The aluminum giant, a component of the Dow Jones Industrial Average, gave the new year's earnings season a boost last week when it reported higher-than-expected record profits for 2006 of $2.90 a share and a 60% boost in net income for the final quarter.   "Results were driven by higher metal prices and strong demand for aluminum in the aerospace, commercial-transportation and commercial-building markets," says Buckingham. "This suggests that commodities like aluminum are in for more years of heavy consumption. Volume levels in those key business sectors remain high, which goes against those who believe commodity prices may be headed back to the low levels of the 1990s."   A consensus of estimates by analysts looks for the company, which also makes Reynold's Wrap and other consumer products, to earn $2.99 a share in 2007 and about the same in 2008.   The outlook is buoyed in part by prospects for continued relatively strong aluminum prices and heavy buying by China, where the company believes demand is growing on average by 14% a year.   Analyst David Martin of Deutsche Bank in New York recently increased his aluminum-price forecast for 2007 to an average of $1.14 a pound, from his prior forecast of $1.11; he lifted his 2008 expectation to $1.01 a pound, from 94 cents previously. The current spot price is $1.22 a pound.   Aluminum has been outperforming other metals of late, notably copper, Martin says, because it is less exposed to the slowing U.S. housing market and has not seen as large an inventory buildup as other metals, he says. Martin rates the stock a Hold.   "Alcoa's priorities and focus have improved via its recent restructuring announcement, and we've become more positive," Martin writes in a recent report. He's keeping a Hold on the shares to see what the restructuring will include.   In other words, investors can expect more thrills as the year unfolds.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) Barron's Online: Ready To Be Re-Energized
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Naureen S. Malik   Investors in Hansen Natural turned fickle toward the No. 2 energy-drink company in last year's second half. But new growth initiatives could put some fizz back into the shares in 2007.   Hansen enjoyed a monster run from 53 cents at the beginning of 2003 to a record $52.72 last July 6 (adjusted for stock splits). But its shares slumped after the company reported in-line second-quarter earnings (much to the disappointment of growth investors used to outsized advances) and an options probe.   At its recent price of $37.08, Hansen (ticker: HANS) was 30% below last year's high, though still triple the price (again, split-adjusted) that it was fetching when Barron's ran a skeptical piece on it a year and a half ago. ("Buzzed to the Max," Aug. 1, 2005.)   Although the stock has bounced back somewhat, there is still upside potential of at least 20%, as Hansen starts to reap the benefits of a deal under which brewer Anheuser-Busch (BUD) will distribute its popular Monster Energy drink, providing marketing muscle and potentially deeper market penetration. Hansen also should benefit from new-product introductions, following a pause in its pipeline last year. In addition, the company is likely to emulate energy-drink leader Red Bull in its recent decision to boost prices.   Les Engebretson, the founder and CEO of Engebretson Capital Management in Newport Beach, Calif., started buying Hansen stock in early 2004 and says the popularity of the beverage maker's energy drinks isn't a fad. "They have been able to take market share away from the others pretty consistently."   He expects earnings to grow another 35%-40% in 2007 from the $1.11 expected in 2006. This compares with 65 cents a share in 2005, 22 cents in 2004 and a mere seven cents in 2003.   Some speculate that the Anheuser relationship ultimately could lead the St. Louis brewing giant to bid for the company. Hansen's chief executive, Rodney Sacks, declined to comment for this article.   With an adjusted cost of roughly $5 a share, Engebretson's firm sold about half of its stake last July for roughly $2 million at around $53 a share. But it became a buyer again near the end of 2006, as Hansen stock dipped to around $30.   Engebretson says that Sacks and Hansen's president, Hilton Schlosberg, manage the company well. The two South Africans purchased Hansen in the 1990s when it was generating roughly $17 million in annual sales. Last year, it probably had $530 million in revenue. "It was a sleepy business that they took over and turned into a remarkable growth story," comments Engebretson.   The beauty of Hansen's business model is that the company doesn't own any manufacturing facilities or make its own drinks. Instead, it relies on a network of producers and distributors with greater economies of scale to make, package and sell its products.   As a result, Hansen has strong cash flow, low capital requirements and costs, and can churn out a new product in as little as six weeks, says Engebretson, whose firm calls Hansen's brass monthly and visits its Corona, Calif., headquarters once or twice a year.   Although Hansen sells over a dozen varieties of fruit juices and carbonated natural sodas, about 90% of its sales are generated by energy drinks. Its top sellers bear the Monster label; others are sold under labels including Lost and Rumba Energy Juice.   In the 13 weeks ended Oct. 28., Monster's 16-ounce cans accounted for $23.4 million of the $100 million U.S. energy-drink market, narrowing the gap with leader Red Bull, which had $33.8 million in sales, according to AC Nielsen.   Energy drinks are the beverage world's fastest-growing segment, with sales expanding roughly 50% in 2006. A Hansen investor presentation in December estimated that convenience stores account for at least 50% of U.S. energy-drink sales.   Goldman Sachs analyst Andrew Sawyer expects the Anheuser-Busch deal to boost Hansen's penetration to 80% at U.S. food and convenience stores, from 55%-65%. That should help it grab some of Red Bull's market by the horns.   This deal could help Hansen sell Monster drinks at bars where Red Bull is popularly mixed with vodka, but only if Hansen can create a similar kind of brand image, says Sawyer. Right now, Hansen's core consumers are 18-to-25-year-old males, with more of a "blue-collar skew" than Red Bull's imbibers, he adds. To create a cooler image, Hansen has been sponsoring extreme and motor sports.   The Anheuser-Busch arrangement should give Hansen more clout with retailers. Hansen stock could see further upside should the company raise its prices, says Goldman Sachs' Sawyer. He expects Monster sales to climb 45% in 2007.   Any good news from Hansen would put pressure on the bears, who've shorted 19% of its 70.2 million publicly traded shares. If they had to cover a substantial portion of their bets, that could boost the stock.   The company, which has just 400 employees, is a potential takeover target, either for Anheuser-Busch or another company, since it has solid financials with low debt and rising cash flow.   On a valuation basis, the stock is trading at 25 times earnings estimates for the next four quarters; it's expected to boast annual earnings growth of at least 20% over that span. Long-term growth is estimated at 36%.   To be sure, Hansen could continue to face downward pressure through the first half of the year during its transition to the Anheuser-Busch distribution system. In some cases, old distributors had become complacent about pushing the product, notes Sawyer.   An options backdating probe and class-action suits could weigh on the stock, as well. The investigation has found that 12,000 shares were "inadvertently" awarded to a director in November 2004 after a grant expired, according to a press release earlier this month. Stock options currently held were also amended. Based on independent analysis of Hansen's option grants, Engebretson contends that the suits have little merit.   Regardless of what happens in the probe, Hansen's sales and profits should grow at a double-digit pace. Shareholders will gladly drink to that.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:10 ET (05:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) Research Reports: How Analysts Size Up Companies
Story: (From BARRON'S)     Edited By Anita Peltonen   The research reports excerpted here were issued recently by investment firms. Many may be obtained through Thomson Financial at www.thomson.com/financial or 800-638-8241. Some are available in the company-research area of WSJ.com, or through Factiva.com. Some of the reports' issuers have provided, or hope to provide, investment-banking or other services to the companies being analyzed.     ARTISTdirect   -- ARTD-OTCBB     Market Perform   -- Price 1.45 on Jan. 17   by JMP Securities     Downgrading to Market Perform [because]: We now expect a significant deceleration in its MediaDefender business in 4Q06, due to . . . a contract dispute with Warner Music [and] slower growth in ARTD's online media business, due to [sales-force hiring] delay. . . . We are lowering our revenue estimate for 2007 from $31.8 million to $27.6 million (consensus: $30.8 million), earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization from $10.4 million to $8.9 million (consensus: $10.3 million). . . . ARTD trades at enterprise value/Ebitda multiple of 7 based on our 2007 Ebitda estimate, a discount to peer-group median of 15 times, which we believe appropriate, given its lower growth rate.     CaremarkRx   -- CMX-NYSE     Outperform   -- Price 56.25 on Jan. 17   by Cowen & Co.     The sweetened terms of the CVS (CVS) merger make the deal more competitive with Express Scripts' (ESRX) competing offer. We think Express can raise its offer by $2 to $3 a share in response. We think CMX shares can outperform the market by 25% over the next year. . . . The $2/share special dividend is a cost-effective method of adding a cash component to the offer. We estimate the share buyback adds 8 to 9 cents to '08 estimated EPS. . . . Pro forma analysis suggests 2008 EPS potential of $2.36.     Commerce Bancorp   -- CBH-NYSE     Underperform   -- Price 34.72 on Jan. 16   by RBC Capital Markets     Q406 EPS increased 54%, year-over-year, but decreased 2.4% sequentially to 40 cents. EPS was two cents below our estimate, but in line with the consensus. . . . EPS missed our estimate due to lower-than-expected average earning-asset growth, lower than anticipated deposit-service-charge income and a lower net-interest margin. U.S. Federal Reserve and the Office of the Comptroller of the Currency have started an investigation . . . that "will include but not be limited to transactions with its officers, directors and related parties, including transactions involving bank premises."     Global Payments   -- GPN-NYSE     Buy   -- Price 38.78 on Jan. 16   by Janney Montgomery Scott     We [recently] hosted a client field trip to Global's main processing facility in Owings Mills, Md. . . . Regarding the stock, catalysts remain elusive due to margin pressure; however, attractive long-term trends in electronic payments could provide support at the $40-per-share level, in our opinion. It appears margins will trend higher as operating efficiencies and overall economies of scale [set in]. . . . We view recently disclosed competitive issues within money-transfer as secondary given this business represents only 4% of pretax earnings. In our opinion, money-transfer challenges were simply the straw that broke the camel's back in regards to tightening '07 revenue guidance to 16% to 17.7%, from 16% to 19%. Reaffirming Buy rating and lowering our 12-month fair value estimate to 48, due to a lack of any material short-term catalysts.     Gray Television   -- GTN-NYSE     Outperform   -- Price 7.79 on Jan. 12   by Barrington Research     We are raising our rating on GTN to Outperform. We are tempted to feel that some important catalysts for Gray will not come fully into play until later in the year, when attention will turn toward the potentially very lucrative 2008 quadrennial election period, which will benefit from a presidential race absent an incumbent from either party. Gray captures about 60% of the political spending in its markets . . . [a] digital switch in 2009 should help its digital duopolies. Recent perking up in the stock leaves it short of other media stocks that have begun to generate longer momentum. We feel additional upside remains, with a 2008-based target of 10.     LeCroy   -- LCRY-NNM     Hold   -- Price 10.35 on Jan. 17   by Needham & Co.     LeCroy is a leading manufacturer of digital oscilloscopes, which are used to visually analyze electronic signals, and serial-data analyzers, which leverage the company's core expertise in high-speed electronic signal acquisition and analysis. The company's products are used in computer, semiconductor, storage, communications and automotive design applications. Although the stock trades at an attractive valuation (16 times our new FY07 estimated EPS) on our reduced estimates after yesterday's sell-off, we are downgrading the stock since the Q2 results [are] yet another in a sequence of apparent execution errors. LeCroy's solution [it is hiring some direct and an army of new indirect salespeople in the U.S. and Asia, and has new products in the pipeline] should play out over the next 12 months. However, we urge caution in case the execution errors continue during that period.     Navteq   -- NVT-NYSE     Buy   -- Price 32.48 on Jan. 17   by American Technology Research     Initiating coverage with a Buy and 44 target. We think Navteq, a maker of digital maps for vehicular navigation, will report [Feb. 8] a strong Q4 . . . current consensus estimates do not reflect dilution from recent acquisitions. The stock is trading at 13 times '07 Ebitda, below our Ebitda growth rate of 16% (depressed by acquisition dilution). Our price target is based on 18 times '07 Ebitda (slight premium to growth) and represents around 38% upside potential.     OMI   -- OMM-NYSE     Buy   -- Price 21.13 on Jan. 16   by Lazard Capital Markets     Reiterating Buy but reducing target to 25 from 27. Our 25 price target equates to 10 times our 2007 EPS forecast and nine times our 2007 enterprise value/Ebitda forecast, in line with the peer-group averages. . . . Lowering 4Q06 estimates and 2007 outlook on softer-than-anticipated freight rates, but OMI still has promise . . . the tanker markets remain historically strong, but freight rates have not met expectations for 4Q06 and 1Q07. After a near record 3Q06 for the Suezmax [one million-barrel capacity] tanker sector, 4Q did not meet our expectations. Handymax and Handysize product tankers are also coming off a strong 3Q, but had a softer-than-expected 4Q.   High U.S. oil inventories and lower-than-expected Chinese demand have led to weaker-than-expected demand from top down for 4Q06, and soften our 2007 outlook. . . . Via its term charter business, OMI is somewhat insulated from future weakness. . . . OMI has an estimated 41% debt to cap and $600 million in liquidity. . . . Colder weather in the U.S. Northeast and declining refined and crude oil inventories could signal improved demand.     Qiao Xing Universal Telephone   -- XING-NNM     Strong Buy   -- Price 12.72 on Jan. 16   by Dutton Associates     XING is one of China's largest manufacturers and distributors of telecommunications products, [sold under] the CECT and COSUN brands, with a product portfolio covering fixed wireless phones, VoIP telephones, advanced mobile phones, PDAs and consumer-electronic products such as MP3 players, cash registers and set-top box products. . . . Although net revenues for the first three quarters of FY2006 were lower than our expectations, we are happy to see significant improvement in gross, operating and net margins [mainly from] cost-control measures . . . and improving product mix toward higher-margin products. This positive trend should extend into FY2007.   In November, XING completed acquisition of the remaining 20% equity in Qiao Xing Mobile Communication, and thus raised its effective interest in CECT (its mobile-handsets operation) from 74.7% to 93.4%. Ministry of Information Industry statistics indicate that the number of mobile subscribers in China is accelerating. These positive factors, along with the improvement in margins, had prompted us to significantly raise our EPS forecasts for fiscal-year 2007 by 16.1% from $2.18 to $2.53.     SumTotal Systems   -- SUMT-NNM     Buy   -- Price 6.36 on Jan. 16   by Wedbush Morgan Securities     Mountain View, Calif.-based SumTotal Systems is the market leader in the enterprise learning-management-systems software sector. Preliminary Q4 results are higher than our above-consensus estimates. . . .   SUMT will release full Q4 results Feb. 6, after the market close. LMS market seems to be growing at a pace, 13% to 17%, that could be double that of the broader application-software market 6% to 7%. We are slightly increasing 2006 revenue estimate from $109.9 million to $110.4 million to reflect preliminary Q4 results. Increasing 2007 revenue estimate from $129 million to $131 million and EPS estimate from 41 cents to 46 cents, due to higher levels of business activity. Raising target to $9.50 (was $8.50), reflecting P/E about 21 times our new '07 EPS estimate of 46 cents.     WellsFargo   -- WFC-NYSE     Buy   -- Price 36.23 on Jan. 16   by Punk Ziegel     Wells Fargo reported 4Q earnings of 64 cents per share, 2 cents below our estimate and flat with 3Q results. The earnings forecasts for WFC are being adjusted as follows: a) the 2007 estimate is being reduced from $2.78 per share to $2.74 per share; b) the 2008 estimate is being increased to $3.07 per share from $3.06 per share; and c) an estimate of $3.37 per share is being instituted for 2009. The price target is being increased to 44 from 42, and the secular growth rate is being raised to 10.5% from 10%.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Gazprom Exec Warns Europe Against Shunning Long-Term Pacts
Story: GELSENKIRCHEN, Germany (AP)--A top executive with Russian natural gas company Gazprom OAO (GSPBEX.RS) on Saturday warned Europe against energy market reforms that would disrupt long-term supply agreements or infringe companies' rights to control their own pipeline infrastructure.   Long-term contracts covering decades shouldn't give way to short-term trading by "speculative firms of the Enron type," said deputy CEO Alexander Medvedev, referring to the high-flying U.S. energy trader that went bankrupt.   "You all know how that turned out," he said.   The E.U. is working on a new energy policy aimed at improving the security of supply and increasing competition, including a proposal to split big energy companies from their distribution networks. Gazprom, the world's largest gas company, which supplies a quarter of Europe's needs, produces gas from its Arctic and Siberian gas fields and also owns a distribution pipe network in Germany through its Wingas partnership with BASF AG's (BF) Wintershall division.   "We are prepared to conduct business to the letter of the law," Medvedev said. "But I think it would be a mistake not to take into account the opinion of gas producers."   He noted that 60% of Wingas' contracts with Gazprom were of one-year duration. "That means Wingas has to show its competitiveness on the market every year," he said.   Much of Gazprom's business, however, is long-term contracts with buyers obligated years in advance to pay whether they use the gas or not, the so-called "take or pay" practice. Medvedev defended the practice as a guarantor of steady supplies.   He also said any liberalization shouldn't deprive companies of control of their pipelines. One form of liberalization sometimes discussed would be to give competitors access to utility companies' pipelines, as has been done with phone lines.   "Access to infrastructure is a condition of reliable gas supply," said Medvedev, who spoke to reports in Gelsenkirchen before a soccer match between FC Schalke and Zenit St. Petersburg. Gazprom sponsors both teams.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 11:36 ET (16:36 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) Fund Of Information: A Hard-To-Beat Benchmark
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lawrence C. Strauss   Chalk one up for the S&P 500, which in 2006 outperformed 69% of large-cap funds.   The indexing versus actively managed fund debate won't be settled anytime soon, if ever. But the latest results, compiled by Standard & Poor's, do highlight how difficult it is for active managers to beat their benchmarks, especially over longer periods.   Last year, the S&P SmallCap 600 surpassed nearly 64% of small-cap funds. On the plus side for active managers, 53.3% of mid-cap funds outpaced the S&P MidCap 400.   Extend the performance period for those three categories to three and five years, however, and the indexes hold a big lead.   From 2000 through 2006, the S&P 500 beat the performance of nearly 57% of large-cap funds, on average. "That shows that over long periods of time, the S&P 500 outperforms the majority of active mutual funds," says Rosanne Pane, mutual-fund strategist at Standard & Poor's.   Countering all  this data is the argument that there are some gifted portfolio managers who are good at picking securities and generating superior returns.   "It's a challenge to outperform the indexes," says Brian McMahon, president and chief investment officer of Thornburg Investment Management, whose four actively managed stock funds beat their benchmarks last year. (A fifth equity fund was launched last year.) "Obviously, we think we can do it because we think we can add value with active management."   The keys to outperformance, he says, are "doing the research and having the judgment and follow-up to apply it."   It's also tougher to outperform as the market narrows, assert investment strategists Richard Bernstein and Kari Pinkernell of Merrill Lynch. In a recent research note, they point out that 48% of the stocks in the S&P 500 beat the index last year -- well below the 57% average this decade.   "We think 2007 is going to be the year where large-caps prevail because of the decelerating profit cycle," says Pinkernell. "Leadership has narrowed in favor of the biggest and the best companies." Such a scenario would favor the S&P 500, which is weighted by market capitalization, over actively managed funds on average.   In a note last summer, Bernstein and Pinkernell argued that narrow markets favor indexing, because it gets tougher to find stocks that will go up in value.   During this decade, more than 50% of large-caps funds beat the benchmark in two separate years, 2000 and 2005. In 2005, energy was a dominant sector, providing a big lift to many active funds. But last year, says Pane of Standard & Poor's, there was a rotation away from energy.   "What we've seen over long periods of time is that when there are major changes in market rotations, the indexes tend to do better," says Pane. "The index is always in those sectors and tends to outperform active managers. It's difficult to make those sector moves."     Closed-end funds have seen their discounts to net asset value decrease. Last month, the median discount fell to 3.63%, continuing a trend that occurred throughout 2006, according to Lipper. This trend was especially true for equity funds.   Unlike open-end funds, closed-end funds have a specified number of shares and trade on an exchange. The price of the fund shares typically trade at a discount or a premium to the fund's underlying assets -- basically, the securities in its portfolio.   Another manifestation of this trend is the Herzfeld Closed-End Average, which is trading at par to its NAV. We plotted that performance against the S&P 500 back over nearly a decade to see if there were any discernible trends between the widening and closing of the average discount and the broad stock market's direction.   We didn't find anything that was particularly convincing or compelling.   "It's a stretch to make the case that there's some kind of a strong correlation or that widening and contraction of discounts can be used as any kind of leading indicator," says Thomas J. Herzfeld, chairman and president of Thomas J. Herzfeld Advisors, a Miami investment firm specializing in closed-end funds.   In the late 1990s, as equities had a big run, the Herzfeld index traded at a big discount to its NAV. Conversely, its discount narrowed and even became a premium between 2000 and 2003 when stocks struggled. But more recently, the discount has narrowed as stocks have done well.   Tom Roseen, a senior research analyst at Lipper, points out that a big factor driving down the discounts is that investors are looking for yield.     Vanguard plans to add four bond exchange-traded funds. The funds, including Vanguard Total Bond Market Index Fund, are expected to have annual expense ratios of a mere 0.11%. Vanguard has filed a registration statement, but the introduction date depends on when the Securities and Exchange Commission approves them.   All four of the exchange-traded funds will be share classes of existing bond funds. These would be the first fixed-income exchange-traded funds offered by Vanguard. The other three offerings would be the Vanguard Short-Term Bond Index Fund, the Vanguard Intermediate-Term Bond Index Fund and the Vanguard Long-Term Bond Index Fund.   Barclays Global Investors, which runs the iShares, has 14 fixed-income ETFs, whose expense ratios range from 0.15% from 0.20%.   ---           Scoreboard          A Downer of a Week     -- U.S. diversified equity funds slipped an average 0.24%, while the broad market gained 0.19% in the week ended Thursday. Large-cap growth funds lost 0.42%, while large-cap value rose 0.46%.  Big funds with strong relative performance included American Funds Euro Pacific fund, up 1.42%, and Dodge & Cox International Stock, which rose 1.63%. : Clues Discovered on Famous Structures Around the World
Story: From San Francisco to Berlin, Thousands Play the World's Largest Puzzle to Win a Trip to Space.       REDMOND, Wash., Jan. 20 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- To celebrate the upcoming consumer release of the Windows Vista(TM) operating system, Microsoft Corp. and AMD have launched "Vanishing Point," the largest puzzle game in the world.  While many clues have been revealed online, parts of the puzzle are being revealed at real-world events including a first-ever takeover of the Bellagio Hotel and Casino fountains and cryptic skywriting messages.  These spectacular sights have driven millions of people to find out more, with hopes of winning the grand prize: a trip to space. Today more clues will be unveiled at some of the most well-known structures in the world.  Projections appearing on the Palace of Fine Arts Theatre in San Francisco, the Brandenburg Gate in Berlin, the National Gallery in London, the Hockey Hall of Fame in Toronto and the Victoria Theater in Singapore will reveal more clues in this mysterious game.        (Logo: http://www.newscom.com/cgi-bin/prnh/20000822/MSFTLOGO)     "Vanishing Point" raises the stakes in online games with tougher challenges, bigger rewards and events scheduled around the globe.  Players worldwide are competing for nearly a half-million dollars in prizes, and the eventual winner will secure a ride to space courtesy of Rocketplane Limited Inc.     "Vanishing Point" challenges players to work together to solve an international game, drawing clues from spectacular events at various locations to decipher online puzzles.  The action hinges on the true identity of the mysterious Microsoft Puzzle Master.  While the Puzzle Master is keeping many details highly confidential, Microsoft has hinted that more offline events could happen later this month.  Representatives will be available to discuss the game, the grand prize and the role Microsoft, Windows Vista and AMD play in the game.  Online conversations about "Vanishing Point" can be found at http://www.technorati.com/search/vanishing+point+game.  More information, official rules and coverage of the offline events are available at http://vanishingpointgame.com.     Microsoft and Windows Vista are either registered trademarks or trademarks of Microsoft Corp. in the U.S. and/or other countries.     The names of actual companies and products mentioned herein may be the trademarks of their respective owners.    SOURCE  Microsoft Corp.       /CONTACT: pr.mspx./ /CONTACT: Jennifer Babbit, +1-404-729-6576, or Jennifer.Babbit@Edelman.com, or Brian Kemp, +1-206-851-5828, or Brian.Kemp@Edelman.com, both of Edelman for Microsoft Corp.      /Web site: http://www.microsoft.com      /Web site: http://www.technorati.com/search/vanishing+point+game      /Web site: http://vanishingpointgame.com/     Order free Annual Report for Microsoft Corporation  Visit http://djnewswires.ar.wilink.com/?link=MSFT or call 1-888-301-0513  (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 07:30 ET (12:30 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(1/22) European Trader: Making A Total Mess In France
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Matthew Curtin and Arindam Nag   The talk that's rife in the French press -- that Finance Minister Thierry Breton has been lobbying hard to displace Christophe de Margerie as the man to follow Total CEO Thierry Desmarest -- isn't doing the company's or France's reputation any good.   France's biggest company by market value, Total (ticker: 12027.France) doesn't need a former government minister bounced into its top job because of unproven allegations against a designated CEO.   Breton has denied doing any such lobbying, and De Margerie continues to have Total's support.   But De Margerie's legal worries have put a cloud over Total's succession plans, and it's no surprise Breton is looking for a new job. Whoever wins France's elections in May, Breton, recruited from France Telecom as a stopgap finance minister, will be replaced.   That may tempt Desmarest to ask Total's board to let him stay as CEO until things calm down. He's to remain chairman anyway.   If the rush to damn Total and De Margerie is unseemly, it is understandable amid the corruption investigations swirling around the French oil giant. The legal heat Total faces is an all-but-inevitable consequence of the French oil company's strategy.   Total's belief is it should go where the oil and gas are. If it doesn't, somebody else will, to the detriment of its shareholders, staff and customers.   Then there's Total's determination to carve out its share of the world's oil and gas reserves, in competition with the U.S. majors, whose geographic room for maneuver has been crimped by Washington's foreign policy.   That has taken Total to countries with unsavory governments of one sort or another --  most notoriously Burma, Iran and Iraq.   Total likes to think of all this as its competitive advantage. But that will be hard to argue if Total executives are found guilty of the corruption they're suspected of in three legal probes in France, related to deals in Iraq, Iran and Cameroon.   But the cases against De Margerie and others aren't proven. And the problem isn't an exclusively French one, despite the memories of the corruption scandals at Elf, bought by Total nearly a decade ago, when it was a state-owned company.   Look at the investigations into war-profiteering by U.S. companies in Iraq, where Halliburton (HAL) has been in the spotlight, and the SEC probe into graft in building a gas plant in Nigeria during the dictatorship of Sani Abacha. The companies under investigation there include Halliburton, Marubeni, and Shell.   What is peculiarly French is the country's justice system, in which it's possible to remain a suspect, questioned by the authorities but not be charged, as an investigation continues, possibly for years.   Jean-Claude Trichet suffered that fate when he was governor of the Bank of France during the probe into Credit Lyonnais. The CEO of Societe Generale, Daniel Bouton, is in a similar position, regarding a money-laundering probe.     The London Stock Exchange has many investors rubbing their hands with glee in announcing another share buyback program.   But the LSE (LSE.London) is making such a habit of impromptu returns of cash to shareholders that the moves, funded by increased debt, are looking like a poison pill-one that may compromise the LSE's longer-term growth.   The additional debt the LSE is taking on, primarily to fend off the bid from Nasdaq (NDAQ), risks making the exchange an unattractive partner for any bidder. It also bars the LSE from making a transforming acquisition of its own without jeopardizing its investment-grade credit rating.   The extra 250 million British pounds in debt that the LSE is taking on, bringing its gross debt to GBP 615 million,  more than doubles its leverage, as measured by net debt to cash flow, to 3.2 times. That could hurt the LSE's future revenue and margins, even if the exchange continues to highlight past growth -- nine-month operating profits doubled to GBP 129 million. The extra debt will likely more than double its interest expense, to GBP 34 million.   The LSE's decision to cut trading tariffs from 90 pence per trade to 20 pence suggests that it's positioning itself for tougher competition. Cracks are also starting to appear in the success of AIM, the LSE's fast-growing junior market.   This all casts doubt over whether incremental earnings growth would be enough to support the LSE's current valuation. The exchange points out that Nasdaq's current offer values it at a little over 24 times earnings, below the 29.8 times of Nasdaq's first offer last March..   But that's still rich enough for the two exchanges to embark on a constructive dialogue, given the LSE's mixed trading outlook and the absence of any other suitors willing to offer that sort of  multiple for the London market.   ---   MATTHEW CURTIN and ARINDAM NAG are contributors to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which this European Trader is based.   ---                         DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES    Region/  Country     DJ Global          DJ Global          DJ Global     Point      Indexes,           Indexes,           Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg. Headline: India ICICI Bank 3Q Net INR9.10 Bln Vs INR6.40 Bln -2
Story: Net interest income for the quarter increased 32% on-year to INR17.09 billion, from INR12.96 billion a year earlier, the bank said.   Fee income increased 53% to INR13.45 billion from INR8.81 billion a year earlier.   "The bank is focusing on non fund-based products and services as well as capitalizing on opportunities presented by the domestic and international expansion of Indian companies," ICICI Bank said in a statement.   The bank reported a capital adequacy ratio as of Dec. 31 of 13.4%.   It said its net non-performing loans in the quarter ended Dec. 31 stood at 1% of total credit.     -By Romit Guha; Dow Jones Newswires; 91-9900181471; romit.guha@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 02:46 ET (07:46 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Thousands In UK Still Without Electricity After Storm
Story: LONDON (AP)--Thousands of people in the U.K. remained without electricity Saturday, two days after fierce storms battered the country.   The east of England was the worst hit, with 19,000 households without power.   EDF Energy (EEN.FR), responsible for much of the area, said it had restored service to around 10,000 customers, but others may not have power until early next week, though it did not say how many.   The storm Thursday killed 14 people in the U.K., and affected swathes of northern Europe, bringing down trees and power lines, and forcing delays for flights and trains.   To tackle the outage, the EDF said it brought in 60 extra engineers from other electricity companies, as well as from its operations in continental Europe.   Meanwhile, 5,000 homes in southern England remained without electricity, along with 2,000 in Wales.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 14:06 ET (19:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Shanghai Pudong Bk: China Banking Regulator OKed JV Fund Co
Story: BEIJING (Dow Jones)--Shanghai Pudong Development Bank Co.'s (600000.SH) planned joint-venture fund-management company with French financial company AXA SA (AXA) has been approved by the country's banking regulator, Ma Li, a deputy president at the Chinese bank, said Saturday.   But the planned joint-venture fund management company still requires approval from the China Securities Regulatory Commission, said Ma on the sidelines of a trade conference in Beijing.   She said the China Banking Regulatory Commission recently gave its approval to the planned joint venture, but didn't give an exact date.   China, which fully opened its banking sector to foreign competition in December in line with its World Trade Organization accession agreement, has urged domestic banks to widen their financial product offerings to compete with rising competition from foreign banks.     -By Terence Poon; Dow Jones Newswires; 8610 6588 5848; terence.poon@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 06:22 ET (11:22 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) 2007 Barron's Roundtable -- Part -5-
Story: Cohen: It is too soon to know exactly what the new Democratic leadership will put forth. But the Democrats identified a small number of economic issues they want to address this year. One is raising the minimum wage. Another will allow the federal government to negotiate with pharmaceutical companies over the price of drugs provided to Medicare recipients. This is now prohibited. Overall, they're trying to keep Medicare pharmaceutical costs from rising too rapidly. Part of that involves trying to negotiate with drug manufacturers. The other part involves a broader use of generics in the formulary used throughout Medicare. Barr will benefit from demographics and these political developments. Thanks for pointing that out, Scott.   My next name is in the energy sector -- Baker Hughes [BHI]. This may not be a great year for energy, but the longer-term patterns are constructive. For much of the past few years, commodity prices dominated share prices. With the commodity now rather dormant, a lot of momentum investors are leaving the sector. Baker Hughes is an "intermission" selection. Our analysts like it because it has less exposure to things like natural-gas prices, which have been hurt by the warm weather. The stock is selling at a discount to some of its peers, like Schlumberger [SLB], in part because of some execution problems at Baker Oil Tools. Our analyst believes the problem will be rectified. The P/E based on this year's earnings is about 13. That is not an unreasonable price to pay for a good, long-term investment.   Gabelli: GE finally decided to get into the oil-services business with the $2 billion purchase of Vetco Gray. They tend to buy not just one company in an area.   Cohen: At past Roundtables I have often talked about technology stocks I like. Tech is a significant portion of the S&P 500. My last stock, Symantec [SYMC], is in the software space. Our tech analysts are more cautious right now than they were a few months ago. Valuations are not as appealing, and we are also very much aware of seasonality, particularly as it relates to hardware. So we're looking at software. The advantage Symantec has is that it has some new products out, including some Norton AntiVirus products. It is in a good category. The stock sells for about 18 times 2007 earnings. Clearly, P/Es are not what they used to be in this category. The stock performed roughly in line with the overall market in 2006, but longer-term earnings growth is on the order of 16%-17%, which is substantially better than the S&P 500. Technology as a category is driven by many factors. Capital spending is not falling off a cliff. Capex [capital expenditures] by U.S. companies in the security category will be 6%-7%. In addition, Symantec sells a consumer product. The stock has been under pressure, given some operational problems late last year. At this entry point, some good returns are available.   Hickey: The big risk for Symantec is that Microsoft [MSFT] is moving into the market. It is a gorilla, and if it is successful, Symantec has trouble. If it's not, Symantec is a good company.   [Tuesday Symantec reported disappointing preliminary third-quarter results, and cut its fiscal '07 forecast. The stock fell about 14% on the week. In an update, Abby said Goldman removed the stock from its Conviction Buy list, though it remains on the firm's Buy list. Goldman's analyst cut her '07 and fiscal '08 forecasts but feels the bad news is reflected in the share price.]     Barron's: Thank you, Abby. Your turn, Felix.   Zulauf: I'm working on the assumption that the economic and financial-markets cycle will run another few years, into the turn of the decade, before a recession hits. Eventually a mania will develop in the market, but for now all the equity markets are extended and due for a correction. Two things: The VIX [volatility index], which is now trading at 12, will shoot up to 20 or even higher. I want to be long volatility this year, via the CBOE Volatility Index.   Second, everything I'd like to buy is not at a buying point now, because the markets are so extended. Don't rush in and buy here. Wait for a correction. My next recommendation is the European telecom industry. An exchange-traded fund such as the DJ Stoxx 600 Telecom [SXKPEX.Germany] is an easy way play it. The story is simple: The industry overexpanded in the late 1990s. Companies overstretched their balances sheets and made all the mistakes one could make. Afterward, stock prices dived from absurd valuation levels. The restructuring process then set in and has been under way ever since. Balance sheets are in good shape again. The investor focus has moved away from this sector, and valuations are attractive.     Barron's: Give us some numbers, please.   Zulauf: At the peak the sector traded for 70 times earnings. Now it trades for about 12 times earnings. In terms of price to cash flow it traded for 250% of the market's valuation, and now trades for about 60%. Dividends were half a percent at the peak, and are now around 4%. They're well covered, at only 20% of cash flow. The telecoms underperformed the European stock market from 2000 until September 2006. They have outperformed since and will continue to do so. While they could pull back in a general market correction, they're much less risky than many other European investments.     Barron's: Why have they rallied?   Zulauf: Some risk-averse investors looked at valuations and saw that industry fundamentals had changed. Telecoms are generating decent free cash flow of about 30 billion euros. The Blackstone Group took a position in Deutsche Telekom [DT]. They are already making money if they sell now. They saw the value.   The industry is not the high-growth business it once was, though there is some sort of growth kicker from the increasing use of broadband and broadband penetration. Return on equity industrywide is about 20%. Analysts in general are neutral or very cautious. I like that, and the fact that European telecom shares sell at a discount of about 15% to 20% relative to U.S. and Asian telecoms. Enterprise value [market value plus net debt] is about eight times operating free cash flow.     Barron's: Where do the ETFs trade?   Zulauf: They trade in Germany. My next recommendation is in Asia -- the Singapore stock market -- though I would definitely wait for a correction. Singapore is a city-state in Southeast Asia. It is only 3.5 times times the size of Washington, D.C., with 4.5 million people, 75% of them Chinese and the rest Malay and Indian. It was founded in 1819 as a British trading colony. It joined the Malaysian Federation in 1963 but separated two years later and became independent. It is probably the best-run country in the world, with an efficient government and a high level of education among its labor force. Singapore has a strong position in international trade because it is on major trade routes. Its port is one of the busiest in the world.   GDP [gross domestic product] per capita is equal to Western Europe. It has a free-market economy that is also free of corruption. Singapore depends heavily on exports, particularly electronics and manufacturing, but the government is trying to grow the economic base. In recent years medical research has been growing nicely, and Singapore now has established a highly competitive financial center. I think it will become the offshore financial center of Asia. As a result, it will benefit greatly from the rise of Asia.     Barron's: How would you invest in Singapore?   Zulauf: Through the iShares MSCI Singapore ETF [EWS]. The index composition is about one-third banks, 17% properties, 10% telecom, 10% multi-industry, 8% transports and 6% retail. The market trades for 1.9 times book value, or a discount of 20% to the world index. It is 10.6 times enterprise value to cash flow and 16 times earnings. The dividend yield is 2.8%, and return on equity is about 13% or 14%. Economic growth in recent years has been between 6% and 8%. In 2006 it was probably 7%. Next year, with the world slowing, it will be 6%. Consumer inflation is 1%. The market could have a correction similar to the one in May-June 2006, when it fell about 20%. I could see another 15%-20% correction in coming months, and would wait to buy into it. Singapore will be higher one year from now, and a lot higher two and three years from now.   Gross: I assume you get some exposure to the Singapore dollar here.   Zulauf: It's an attractive currency, probably one of the best around. Currently it is weak because it is misused like the yen and Swiss franc as a refinancing currency because interest rates are very low. That has a somewhat depressing effect on the currency. Longer term it will catch up and the fundamental strengths will come through.   Cohen: You're playing it both ways in terms of liking it but calling it too expensive. What is the catalyst for a market correction, and for another rally?   Zulauf: There is no specific catalyst other than trends in world markets. Singapore was always regarded as well managed, but people weren't sure it would be accepted as a stand-alone government and country. Over the years, in particular the past 10, it has demonstrated it is capable of moving into new, value-added industries. Eventually, Singapore will be a classic way to play the rise of Asia and the mania I see coming. A lot of financial companies and multinationals are choosing to locate there.   Cohen: It is also less polluted than Hong Kong, which is one reason for the recent migration of businesses.   Zulauf: It's a bit humid, and Marc would probably say the night life is not attractive enough. But that is improving, and casinos will come, too.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Alitalia Says Not Able To Update Strategy For 2007-09
Story: MILAN (Dow Jones)--Italy's struggling airline Alitalia (AZA.MI) said late Friday it has ditched plans to present an industrial strategy for 2007-09, but would draw up a budget for the current year by the end of January.   Alitalia's board had been due to meet on Friday to discuss the industrial plan, but the meeting was canceled after Jean-Cyril Spinetta, CEO of Air France-KLM (3112.FR), resigned Thursday, leaving the board with fewer than the mandatory three members.   The Italian government has put the ailing airline up for sale, asking for expressions of interest by Jan. 29, and Spinetta's departure triggered market speculation that Air France-KLM might finally be persuaded to bid.   Air France-KLM said Spinetta's resignation - over two weeks after Rome announced its plans - was due to a conflict of business interests caused by the government's announcement.   Italy's center-left government, which holds 49.9% of Alitalia, said at the end of 2006 it wanted to sell at least 30.1%, a stake that would legally oblige the buyer to launch a full offer for the carrier.   Alitalia hasn't posted an annual profit since 2002.   It said on Friday it couldn't confirm or deny reports that it had lost about EUR400 million last year.      -By Giada Zampano, Dow Jones Newswires; 39-3487678016; giada.zampano@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 07:39 ET (12:39 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Popolare Italiana Hldrs Vote To Reinstate Gronchi As CEO
Story: MILAN (Dow Jones)--Shareholders in Banca Popolare Italiana (BPI.MI) Saturday voted to reinstate Chief Executive Divo Gronchi, who had been suspended from official duties last month after being convicted for his role in the collapse of real estate group Bagaglino.   In a statement, Popolare Italiana said 1,885 shareholders voted to reinstate Gronchi, on a total of 2,847 who turned up at the meeting in Lodi near Milan.   Gronchi is one of the main architects of the planned merger with fellow Italian cooperative bank Banco Popolare di Verona e Novara (BPVN.MI), which will create Italy's third-largest bank by number of branches.   Gronchi, who is pushing through a turnaround at the Lodi-based bank, was suspended in December along with other top Italian bankers following his conviction for a role in the bankruptcy of real estate and hotel company Italcase-Bagaglino.   Popolare Italiana shareholders are expected to vote on the merger with Popolare Verona in mid-March.   The new bank will focus its business on both savings and loans, to both its own shareholders as well as non-shareholders, based on the principles of popular credit, with particular attention to the territory where its subsidiary banks operate and where the group has its branch network, the two banks said in December.     -By Giada Zampano, Dow Jones Newswires; 39-3487678016; giada.zampano@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 10:34 ET (15:34 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) Plugged In: Tech Earnings' Blow-Ups And Blow-Outs
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   A gusty breeze has been blowing across Techland, propelled by a stream of December quarter-earnings whiffs.   SAP (ticker: SAP), Motorola (MOT), and Symantec (SYMC, see page 18) are just a few of the underperformers leading this parade of strikeouts. Of course, Apple (AAPL) has been an exception.   One big reason is that information-tech orders in the United States are down 10%-20% from their level a year ago, says Dresdner Kleinwort economist Tatha Ghose. New orders for equipment fell sharply during the latter part of 2006, with growth rates "turning steeply negative." What's more, this may not be just an American phenomenon. Similar trends are occurring in Japan and the rest of Asia, which isn't always the case. "This is a more synchronized downturn," Ghose notes.   What's happening?   Steep drops in orders typically occur when customers are aggressively cutting inventory to adjust for lower demand. These downturns usually don't last long, says Ghose, who predicts that orders should bounce back sharply during the first half. Once customers finally burn off their excess demand, orders often snap back with a short, abrupt spike, which he expects to hit before July.   But don't get your hopes too high. The rebound will be short-lived because the factors causing lower demand will continue to deteriorate, he posits. In fact, the one-time uptick in orders "should quickly fizzle out in a powerful whiplash," Ghose says. The original demand slowdown, which caused the inventory glut, is likely to worsen. That's why Ghose says he's telling a "downbeat story," longer-term.   Optimists point to the stellar performance of the second half of last year -- after a lousy first six months -- as reason not to panic. But Ghose maintains that fundamentals -- such as capital-spending growth -- were still weakening in last year's second-half boomlet, setting tech up for some painful quarters, starting in the fall. Here's hoping he's wrong.     Now, for something completely different. Apple's earnings are the flip side to our January of disappointment. The electronics maker had record profits in its fiscal first quarter, whipping consensus estimates by 46%. How many Nanos did you give as presents over the holidays?   Apple sold more than 21 million of the handheld music players, up about 50% from the total a year earlier. Still, the stock didn't benefit, as the company's projections for the rest of the year were typically sanguine. Its shares closed at 88.50, off 7% after the earnings report.   But the profits fun doesn't stop here, says Goldman Sachs analyst David Bailey. "Apple's over-the-top December quarter results punctuate what has been a really strong year for the company, as well as starts the clock on what should be the next big growth phase," he comments.   The analyst actually lowered his estimates slightly for the first half as the company introduces new products, such as Intel-powered Macs with new operating systems. But he raised his estimates for this calendar year and 2008, based on high expectations for meaningful contributions from the recently unveiled iPhone smartphone. Bailey raised his price target to 110 from 102.   While there are some concerns that the iPhones might be too pricey at about $400 and $500, there already are suggestions that Apple plans to reduce prices systematically, as it has on items such as the iPod.   iSuppli, a supply-chain research outfit, predicts that every iPhone sold initially will produce about a 50% gross margins for Apple and its carrier, AT&T. That leaves room"for aggressive price declines going forward," says Jagdish Rebello, a director and principal analyst at iSuppli.   Apple will need it. iSuppli says there are 14 music-enabled mobile phones like iPhone already available from Nokia, Motorola, Samsung and LG. Let the music play.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:10 ET (05:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Japan Gas Leak Death Toll Rises To 3; 2nd Leak Discovered
Story: TOKYO (AP)--The death toll from a carbon monoxide gas leak in northern Japan rose to three, officials said Saturday, and utilities workers found a new leak near the disaster site while inspecting the underground pipes.   Another eight people remained hospitalized from the leak that was discovered Friday in the city of Kitami, on Japan's northern island of Hokkaido. Hokkaido Gas Co. (9534.TO) officials were checking lines for more leaks Saturday, police official Yoshimi Ikeda said.   Another leak was found about 3 kilometers from the first leak, but no one suffered ill effects, he said.   The gas is believed to have originally escaped from a ruptured pipe beneath a sidewalk into the sewage system and then into nearby homes. Utility workers repaired the pipe and contained the leak Friday.   Nearly 200 people were ordered evacuated, but the order was later lifted in most areas. No fires or explosions were reported.   Metal fatigues is being suspected as the cause of the cracked pipe. The pipe was installed about 40-years ago and last checked in November 2004, according to Hokkaido Gas Co.   The local fire department responded after Hokkaido Gas notified it that residents were complaining of the smell of gas in their neighborhood. Kitami is about 970 kilometers northeast of Tokyo.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 02:41 ET (07:41 GMT)

Headline: : ICICI Bank Announces Performance -4-
Barron's(1/22) 2007 Barron's Roundtable -- Part -2-
Story: Gross: It's possible. It's half absurd to suggest that a 25-basis-point overnight rate, or even 0.50%, is excessive, though in the past five years it was hardly excessive to be close to zero percent. It took that simply to get the economy above the line. Japan is in a demographic trap that will be difficult to get out of. Resuming or moving to a path that the rest of the world considers normal in terms of short-term rates is excessive.   Zulauf: They have drained too many reserves. Soon the Bank of Japan will come out with a revision of loan growth. The old number showed a nice pickup in loan growth in the past 12 months, but I hear the new number will show it was flat for the whole period and the economy was not doing as well as perceived.   Gross: I agree with that. The problem in Japan is the consumer, who is older relative to almost all parts of the rest of the world, barring Italy and maybe Germany.
