It's going to be very difficult to get consumption up in Japan. It is an export-dominated economy, and they have seen their best growth for the next few years.   My third pick is a plain, old-fashioned Pimco closed-end fund, Pimco Strategic Global Government Fund [RCS]. As Barron's readers know, I have been a supporter of closed-end funds. When purchased at net asset value or at discounts to NAV, they can be attractive. They can be bought easily, much like a stock on the New York Stock Exchange, which in fact is where they are listed. I've done lots of personal investing in municipal closed-end funds, buying them at 10% and 15% discounts. Typically, over time, those discounts close up, and that's one way of getting potential appreciation. The other is that you're buying $1.15 of assets for a buck. I like to do that.     Barron's: Aren't there some negatives?   Gross: One negative is that most closed-end funds are levered; they tend to have 50% leverage, borrowing at overnight lending rates or preferred-money-market rates. That allows them to provide higher yields. When you have a flat-to-negative yield curve, the leverage tends to work against you, as it does in most asset classes.   Pimco Strategic Global Government is a plain-vanilla, triple-A-type government fund. It doesn't invest in emerging markets. You won't find Brazilian or Argentine bonds in it. You'll find U.S. bonds and some of the Japanese bonds I just talked about. There's very little credit risk; most of the risk is related to interest-rate movements and leverage. This is a dollar-based fund. It yields 7.5%, even with triple-A government bonds. Is the dividend at risk? My lawyers would always counsel me to say that dividends are at risk. They are simply voluntary disbursements on the part of corporations. This dividend was cut because of the increasing cost of leverage about five months ago, though I expect it to be stable for the rest of 2007.     Barron's: How does the fund trade relative to NAV?   Gross: It trades at a 2% premium to net asset value, though I'd prefer to buy it at a discount. I'd like to underline for readers the importance of timing with regard to all investments, but particularly closed-ends, because they are thinly capitalized and thinly traded. You're talking 30,000 or 40,000 shares a day here. You don't want to place an order for thinly traded stocks or funds without recognition of potential price movements. You want to make sure your order reflects value. Don't go rushing in thinking you are capturing a 7.50% yield and give your broker a market order. Make sure it's price-specific, and that you're not taken to the cleaners by the bid-asked spread or by a rush of orders in the days after publication. That's critical for many of these recommendations.   Faber: In the U.S., the 30-year bond is yielding around 4.75%, and in Europe government bonds yield less than 4%. How does this fund achieve a 7.50% dividend? Does it invest in emerging-market debt?   Gross: Not at all. It invests in a lot of U.S. mortgages, which start out yielding 5.50% to 6%. Then there's the 50% leverage.   Faber: A few years ago you were negative about stocks. Yet, your first recommendation, the iShares MSCI EAFE, was a stock fund. Are you still bearish on stocks?   Gross: No. That doesn't mean they're not at risk, but at current multiples, both here and in Europe, as a risk asset class they rank relatively high. We have levered risk assets in many areas to levels that are inappropriate and almost ridiculous. To toss stocks into the basket is a mistake, however. That doesn't mean they won't go down in the short term, but they are decently valued compared to all other risk assets.   My last recommendation, BlackRock Floating Rate Income Strategies Fund [FRA], is another closed-end. It was issued by BlackRock -- I like to spread the wealth around -- and continues to be managed by the firm. It doesn't have interest-rate risk. This one has credit risk. There are about 10 or 15 of this class of floating-rate income closed-end funds; Pimco offers two. They are bank-loan oriented. The BlackRock offering makes bank loans, most of which are Ba-rated, plus or minus. They can be loans to rather major corporations.     Barron's: What is the duration on most of them?   Gross: Most of the loans have a term of about five years, with call provisions less than that. Thus, the life of the loan, depending upon the attractiveness of the spread, can be five years or less. But by the nature of the instrument, they adjust on a quarterly basis to changes in the fed-funds rate, and in LIBOR [London interbank offered rate]. That's why these funds have appreciated in price significantly in the past year or two. As the Fed has raised interest rates to 5.25%, these funds have benefited directly. Their dividends have gone higher and higher. If I'm wrong in terms of my Fed forecast and the Fed goes to 6% as opposed to 4.25%, BlackRock Floating Income would be able to add 75 basis points of yield simply on the basis of short-term money-market instruments. There is protection interest-rate-wise here.   The risk is on the credit side. Despite the bank-loan nature of the instruments, these are B-rated or Ba-rated securities for the most part of levered or semi-levered corporations. Reynolds American [RAI] is an example of a bank loan that can be purchased in the open market and by these funds. General Motors [GM] has a number of recently issued floating-rate loans that funds such as this have bought. Ford [F] has some. We are talking about Ba and B-rated securities that have some credit risk, but also interest-rate protection, which is a diversifier.     Barron's: Are they subordinate to other borrowers?   Gross: No, they are senior to other borrowers. A bank loan is almost always senior to other straight, and in some cases subordinated debt issued by a corporation. If a company fails, historically holders of bank debt recover on the order of 75 to 80 cents on the dollar, whereas a typical debt instrument would recover 40 cents. You have principal protection here from bank loans as opposed to normal debt instruments, so I like their long-term credit protection. I also like this fund because of its yield. It has an 8.10% yield that will hold at this level or maybe go a little higher over time. The fund has been conservative in terms of its dividend. The yield on most floating-rate closed-end funds approaches 9%.   In addition, the fund sells at a 6% discount to net asset value. You are buying a portfolio of loans initiated by banks and then sold, in this case to BlackRock, at a 6% discount. You're paying 106 or 106.5 cents for a buck. I prefer to buy this at a 10% discount, but 6% isn't bad for a floating-rate closed-end fund.   Gabelli: That's a great idea. Is it taxable?   Gross: This one is taxable, so it is better owned in an individual retirement account. Those are my picks.     Barron's: Thank you. Archie?   MacAllaster: I'm glad you asked me to speak before John, because my favorite stock is on his list. It's Lyondell Chemical [LYO], and it trades for 25.03. The earnings estimate for 2006 is $3.25 a share. The stock has ranged from 27.60 to 18.86; now it's closer to the high. Book value is $15 a share. My '07 estimate is $4-plus. They can earn quite a bit more than that, but I'm holding it at $4 and a lot of analysts who follow the stock are estimating a lot less. There must be a dozen or 14 who follow it.   Neff: That's a good number. It's the third-biggest chemical company in the U.S.   MacAllaster: I was about to say that. Lyondell owns 100% of a large oil refinery in Houston; it bought the Venezuelans' 41% stake. The company indicated recently that the refinery was earning about $2.20-$2.25 a share. The chemical operation will have more than $21 billion of annual revenue this year, and the company has added sales at very little cost to shareholders. Some might even say you're getting the chemical company for free, but that's probably a slight exaggeration. The dividend is 90 cents a share, and the yield is 3.5%. This is a global company; about 40% of its chemical operations are overseas.   I like to compare Lyondell to the No. 2 chemical company, DuPont [DD], which sells for 48. I'm not saying DuPont is a buy or a sell. Lyondell's sales in '07 will be about $29 billion. DuPont's are estimated to be $29.5 billion. Lyondell probably earned $3.25-$3.30 in '06, against $2.80 for DuPont. In '07, as I told you, my estimate is $4 a share for Lyondell, versus $3.25 for DuPont. Just remember, DuPont sells for 48, Lyondell for 25.50.   Gabelli: I am not going to defend DuPont, but a huge amount of its earnings comes from bioengineered seeds. It is the second- or third-largest seed company, so it gets a much higher valuation.   MacAllaster: The way I look at it, Lyondell is dirt cheap.   Witmer: Does it have much debt?   Neff: Monster debt, huge.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Analex Announces Merger Agreement With QinetiQ
Story: FAIRFAX, Va., Jan. 20 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Analex Corporation (Amex: NLX), a leading provider of mission-critical professional services to U.S. federal government clients, today announced that it has signed a merger agreement with QinetiQ North America Operations LLC, a leading technology development and technical services company and a subsidiary of the British firm, QinetiQ Group plc.  Under the terms of the merger agreement, QinetiQ will commence a cash tender offer to acquire all of Analex's outstanding shares of common stock for $3.70 per share.  The merger agreement has been approved by the boards of directors of both companies.     Following completion of QinetiQ's tender offer, any remaining shares of Analex common stock will be acquired by QinetiQ in a cash merger at the same per share price.  The transaction will result in Analex becoming a wholly owned subsidiary of QinetiQ North America.  The transaction is subject to customary conditions, including the receipt of regulatory approvals and the tender of at least the majority of the outstanding Analex shares.     Sterling Phillips, Analex's Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, stated, "The merger with QinetiQ provides a significant premium over the current trading price of Analex common stock.  The Board of Directors believes the transaction maximizes the value of Analex to stockholders.  We believe the size, growth and global competitiveness of QinetiQ also provide excellent opportunities for Analex's employees and customers."     Commenting on the agreement, QinetiQ North America's Chief Executive Officer Duane Andrews said, "Analex promises to be an excellent addition to the QinetiQ North America business profile, providing important new customer relationships within the security agencies, the Department of Defense and NASA as well as broadening our existing service offerings."  He continued, "Analex will further enhance QinetiQ North America's position of being able to bid for a wider range of significant opportunities in the defense and security market place in North America."     The Board of Directors of Analex and the Special Committee of the Board formed for purposes of this transaction each have unanimously approved the transaction and will recommend the transaction to the stockholders of Analex. Analex Corporation is being represented in this transaction by BB&T Capital Markets | Windsor Group, a division of Scott & Stringfellow, Inc., as its exclusive sell-side advisor and provided a fairness opinion relating to the transaction.  Raymond James & Associates, Inc. also provided a fairness opinion relating to the transaction.        Notice to Investors     This announcement does not constitute an offer to purchase or a solicitation of an offer to sell any securities. The tender offer for Analex's outstanding common stock described in this press release has not commenced. Any offers to purchase or solicitation of offers to sell will be made only pursuant to a tender offer statement and a solicitation and recommendation statement filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The tender offer statement (including an offer to purchase, a letter of transmittal and other offer documents) and the solicitation/recommendation statement will contain important information and should be read carefully before any decision is made with respect to the tender offer. Those materials will be made available to all stockholders of Analex at no expense to them. In addition, all of those materials (and all other offer documents filed with the SEC) will be available at no charge on the SEC's web site at http://www.sec.gov.        About QinetiQ North America     QinetiQ North America ("QNA") provides world class technology and responsive solutions to U.S. Government customers. QNA has over 3,000 engineers and technologists working in partnership with its customers to develop innovative technology solutions to meet the challenges of national defense, homeland security, and information access. Strengthened by the legacy of its previous acquisitions of Apogen Technologies, Foster-Miller, Planning Systems, and Westar Aerospace and Defense Group, QinetiQ North America proudly serves customers in the areas of System Engineering and Technical Support, Information Technology Services, and Technology Development.  QinetiQ North America is a wholly-owned subsidiary of QinetiQ, one of the world's leading defense and security technology companies. QinetiQ was founded from the world's first top flight national defense laboratory (UK Ministry of Defense, Defense Evaluation and Research Agency). QNA's affiliation with QinetiQ gives customers access to the output of 50 years of national investment at the forefront of technology.        About QinetiQ     QinetiQ (pronounced ki' ne tik as in 'kinetic energy') is a leading international defense and security technology company.  Founded in July 2001 from the majority of the Defence Evaluation and Research Agency (DERA), the laboratories of the UK Ministry of Defense (MOD), QinetiQ today has over 11,400 employees in the UK and U.S., who deliver technology-based services and solutions.  QinetiQ North America, operated under a separate U.S. proxy Board, has also acquired the U.S. businesses of Apogen Technologies, Inc., Foster- Miller Inc and Westar Aerospace & Defense Group.  These businesses have subsequently made further acquisitions to date that include Planning Systems Inc and Ocean Systems Engineering.  QinetiQ shares trade on the London Stock Exchange under the symbol "QQ."  Visit www.QinetiQ.com for further information.        About Analex     Analex (www.analex.com) specializes in providing intelligence, systems engineering and security services in support of our nation's security. Analex focuses on developing innovative technical approaches for the intelligence community, analyzing and supporting defense systems, designing, developing and testing aerospace systems and providing a full range of security support services to the U.S. government.  The Company's stock trades on the American Stock Exchange under the symbol NLX.     PLEASE NOTE: Statements in this press release relating to the proposed transaction, and other statements relating to the businesses of the companies, their plans, strategies, economic performance and trends and other statements , including statements containing the words "anticipate," "believe," "could," "expect," "intend," "may," "plan," "potential," "should," and "will," and similar expressions which are not descriptions of historical facts are forward-looking statements under the provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995, Section 27A of the Securities Act of 1933, as amended, and Section 21E of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended. Forward-looking statements are not guarantees of future performance and are subject to risks, uncertainties and other factors that could cause our actual results to differ materially from those expressed or implied by these statements.  In addition to those risks specifically mentioned in the reports filed by the Company with the Securities and Exchange Commission (including the Company's Form 10-K for the most recently completed fiscal year), such risks and uncertainties include, but are not limited to: the Company's dependence on contracts with U.S. federal government agencies, particularly within the U.S. Department of Defense and NASA, for substantially all of our revenue; changes in the spending priorities of the federal government; government contract procurement and termination risks; competitive factors such as pricing pressures and/or competition to hire and retain employees (particularly those with security clearances); the likelihood of success in growing the Company's business through acquisition or otherwise, including the risk that the expected benefits of the acquisition may not be realized; growth in the government contracting arena and in the economy in general.  These forward looking statements reflect the Company's current beliefs; however developments and events subsequent to this document are likely to cause these statements to become outdated.  We undertake no obligation to update these forward-looking statements to reflect new information, future events or otherwise, accept as provided by law.        Contact:  Amber Gordon                    (703) 852-1392        SOURCE  Analex Corporation       /CONTACT: Amber Gordon, +1-703-852-1392      /Web site: http://www.analex.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 10:05 ET (15:05 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(1/22) The Electronic Investor: Websites That Earn Their Keep
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kathy Yakal   When you're shopping for a new washing machine, you probably wade through reams of features and performance measures to try to find the model that gives you the most desired attributes for the fewest dollars.   Buying stocks isn't so different.   Arguably the most important measure for assessing a stock's performance and value is earnings per share (EPS), or a company's profits devoted to earnings divided by its number of outstanding shares of common stock. It can tell you whether the issuing company is profitable, if those profits are growing or contracting and, in conjunction with the stock price, just how expensive the shares are. An analogous figure for a washing machine might give you an idea of its quality, reliability and its cost, relative to its peers.   Not surprisingly, a lot of financial Websites offer EPS news, projections and analysis, and, given that we've just embarked on a new earnings season (for the fourth quarter of 2006), I thought it would be a good time to explore what's available.   First, keep in mind that earnings announcement dates aren't carved in stone. Companies sometimes are reticent to commit to lengthy advance notice about when they'll report; worse, some posted dates can be inaccurate. Still, there are watchdog sites that attempt to keep pace with the most likely dates.     Analysts who follow public companies make their earnings estimates available to various services that compile them into averaged, or "consensus," estimates. One of the best places to get a quick peek at these estimates is Yahoo! Finance (finance.yahoo.com). Type in a symbol for a quote, then click Analyst Estimates. You'll see stats on current earnings and revenue forecasts; history, trends and revisions. You'll also find profit-growth estimates, compared to market benchmarks'.   Yahoo! Finance -- like most major general investing sites -- provides a daily calendar of earnings announcements and access to conference calls and earnings releases. It also chronicles surprises: profits that beat or fall short of the consensus.   Zacks Investment Research (www.zacks.com), which pioneered consensus estimates and EPS surprises, also provides coverage. Go to www.zacks.com/research/earnings for its free information. You'll find a calendar of coming announcements, summaries of earnings news, declarations of profits and revisions of estimates.   But Zacks isn't just for earnings estimates anymore. It provides an impressive array of data, analysis and tools for general market research. Zacks Premium, which costs $24.95/month or $199/year, includes content like proprietary stock rankings, custom screening and investment strategies. For investors who want research tools plus stock-picking help, Zacks is one of the best bargains in this class.   Another paid Zacks' service is the Surprise Trader, which uses a proprietary indicator to predict which stocks will rise in the weeks following an earnings announcement. It's pricey, $1,495 per year, but the Surprise Trader does carry a money-back guarantee.   You can also browse earnings calendars on the free side of Briefing.com, one of the best sites for keeping track of fast-breaking numbers and related analysis. More active traders should consider its Platinum service ($29.95/month or $300/year). Under the Calendars tab, you'll find numerous entries related to earnings. There's a calendar with estimates from both Reuters and Zacks. Confirmed dates are check-marked; others are tentative.   Monthly calendars by sector are also displayed, as are current earnings surprises. Still another series of pages displays 30 days of "earnings guidance" --  companies' own judgments about their future performance. Colored arrows indicate whether a company's earnings are running above, below or in line with consensus forecasts. Revenue estimates are also provided.   Probably the simplest, fastest place we found for basic calendar info is Earnings.com, powered by Thomson Street Events (www.streetevents.com). This is also a good (and free) source of information on splits and dividends, initial public offerings, conferences and Webcasts.   Not all earnings estimates are compiled by analysts. "Whisper numbers" reflect the earnings world's rumor mill, figures bandied about by trading desks, chat rooms and blogs, and on various Websites. The best of the latter group is Earnings Whispers.com, an old-timer in Web years (and it looks like the site's interface hasn't been updated since we first looked at it many years ago). Free services include a calendar of verified and tentative announcements, news and discussion.     Those who operate behind Earnings Whispers.com's basic subscriber wall ($14.95/month) get daily updates on the compiled whisper numbers, on the site and in an e-mail. Each company covered is represented in a good one-page profile that includes a wrap-up of the current quarter with the related outlook and trends. An alert flashes if there's a new "whispering," which is an EPS prediction from a source whom the service identifies by name. A premium service ($99.95/ month) offers more depth and breadth that can lead to trading opportunities based on more credible whispers. Both the basic and premium versions, however, can aid traders.   WhisperNumber.com assembles its earnings whisper numbers based on the views of individual investors. Interesting to see, but I'm not sure I'd bet the bank on these numbers.   There are other sites that will lighten your wallet a bit but could also provide helpful bits and pieces of your earnings research. The Fly on the Wall (www.theflyonthewall.com) sends market-breaking news and earnings predictions from the pros out to subscribers all day long; $25/month. Wall Street Horizon (www.wallstreethorizon.com) claims to have the most comprehensive and accurate earnings dates and conference-call schedule. (I was impressed.) The site's analysts speak with reporting companies regularly. It runs $695/year for institutional investors; half that for individuals. That's about the price of a solid, dependable washing machine  -- well worth the cost if it helps you locate a high-quality stock.   ---   e-mail: electronicinvestor@yahoo.com   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) 2007 Barron's Roundtable -- Part -3-
Story: MacAllaster: Had they sold their portion of the Houston refinery, they would have reduced their debt considerably. But on the other side of the equation, the refinery's cash flow is enormous. They did a smart thing. The debt will come down rapidly. They've already reduced it by $2 billion or $3 billion. My target on the stock is 40.   My second stock is Hartford Financial Services. I'm doing relative values this year. In 2005, they earned $7.60 a share, and mind you, that was the year with all the hurricanes. They have a very balanced financial business in annuities, life insurance, general insurance, and fire and casualty. The earnings estimate for 2006 is $9 a share. For '07 it's $9.70. The P/E based on '07 results is about 9.5. The dividend yield is 2.15%. Return on equity is about 15%, and book value is about $58 a share. The company sells for about 1.6 times book. The growth rate is about 10%. Hartford has raised its dividend in each of the past nine years, and its P/E in the past few years has been about 12. Hartford also has a large stock-buyback program of $5 billion, roughly 2% of outstanding stock.     Barron's: Where is the stock?   MacAllaster: The stock sells for 91.67, and my target price is 115-120. Hartford is a large company, with more than $300 billion of total assets. Prudential Financial [PRU] is a little less than $400 billion and MetLife [MET] is a little over $500 billion. They both sell for 15-16 times '07 earnings. Hartford sells for less than 10 times. They yield about 1.1%, Hartford more than 2%. On a relative basis, Hartford is a good buy.   Next, I've got a new insurance company, in business since 2001. It's Arch Capital [ACGL].   Gabelli: I love the name, Arch.   MacAllaster: I wish that Arch were me. The stock sells for 66.77. Earnings per share in '05 were $3.84. In '06 they should have earned about $8.50, and in '07 they will probably do about $8.50 again, because premiums are going to come down. They'll be lucky to earn the same $8.50. This is a Bermuda company. Though it's relatively new, it has experienced insurance executives and a solid book of business. It has always shown an operating profit, even in 2005, with all the hurricanes. The combined ratio -- expenses and losses -- was 95.8% in 2005. Arch does general insurance and reinsurance. It has 74 million shares outstanding and $13 billion of total assets. Book value is about $45, so it sells for 1.5 times book. The balance sheet is clean, and very important, it doesn't have a lot of old problems, spelled "asbestos." It's a cheap stock with a long way to go. My target is 90.   Black: We own a few Bermuda reinsurers. Whether it's RenaissanceRe [RNR] or IPC [IPCR] or Arch, they had a benign year. They aren't going to get much multiple expansion because there's such volatility in weather year to year.   MacAllaster: When you're paying 90 bucks for $8.50 of earnings, that's not a high multiple.   Black: I'm not convinced they're going to sell at 10 and 11 times earnings. Many are selling at 6.5 and 7 times earnings now.   MacAllaster: All I'm saying is that this is a high-quality company. It has experienced people, and they started it fresh. I think they will increase assets massively year after year, and on a long-term basis you're going to make money in it.   Gabelli: How much of the business is old-fashioned property and casualty, and how much is reinsurance?   MacAllaster: It's about 40%-plus general insurance and 55% reinsurance. Now, on to Capital One Financial [COF]. We all see their ads on television. The stock trades on the Big Board [New York Stock Exchange] for 77.16. In 2005 they earned $6.80 a share. The estimate for 2006 is $7.75, and for '07 it's $8.25. [The company reported 2006 earnings of $7.62 a share Thursday.] The stock sells for under 10 times '07 estimated earnings. Capital One is the last remaining large credit-card company that hasn't been taken over by some other financial institution.   Black: They've been buying. They bought North Fork Bancorp, among others.   MacAllaster: They also bought Hibernia. They will end up with more than $150 billion of banking assets, which puts them in the top 15 in terms of asset size among U.S. banks. The company has a reasonable banking business, with 700-800 branches. It has gone international in its credit-card business. It's deserving of a higher multiple -- say, the 12 times earnings a lot of banks sell for. People are starting to look at it more as a bank. The American Banker named Capital One's CEO, Richard Fairbank, banker of the year. Earnings growth could be 7%-9%, and my target price is 90.   Black: We owned North Fork and opted to sell it because 32% of Capital One's portfolio is Alt-A [alternative documentation] and sub-prime loans. This is an accident waiting to happen. Some home buyers with option ARMs [adjustable-rate mortgages] have negative equity now.   MacAllaster: The company manages it well. I think you made a mistake. The 52-week range on Capital One is 69.30 to 90.04.   Switching to technology, it's time to buy Corning [GLW] again. Everyone here will probably tell me I'm wrong on this one, but I've bought and sold it for a lot of years, and made money on it. I'm recommending it in a range. There are speculators in Corning big-time, both up and down. The stock sold as high as 29.61 this year and as low as 17.50, and it's now 19.04, very close to the lows of the year. A lot of the selling seemed to come about because prices have been cut 40%, 50%, 60% on the new televisions for which they make glass panels. They probably have 45% of the business. By lowering prices, however, TV manufacturers are going to sell many more units.   Witmer: Archie, if you walk around on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, old Sony TVs, like WEGAs, are out on the street.   MacAllaster: Everybody wants a new one.   Hickey: The problem is, there's such a glut now. That's why prices have fallen so much. For example, LCD [liquid crystal display] TV prices fell by 50% more than Circuit City had budgeted, and plasma-TV prices have plummeted more than three times expectations. It's so bad that the second-largest flat-panel maker, LG Philips, is cutting its capital spending this year by 67% compared with last year. AUO Optronics [AUO], Chi Mei Optoelectronics [3009.Taiwan], and other panel makers are cutting production right now. As they cut, Corning's glass orders go down.   MacAllaster: You're probably short.   Hickey: I'm not short Corning.   MacAllaster: Then I'd better add quickly that they have other businesses. The company makes about 22% on capital. It has about $1 billion-$1.4 billion in debt and about $2 billion of liquid assets. Corning is in diesel controls, which should do well with the surge of interest in the environment. The company has had a great history of innovation. It will earn $1.05-$1.10 for 2006, and $1.25-$1.30 this year. It is cheap compared to most technology companies.     Barron's: You're confident about '07 earnings?   MacAllaster: They ought to be able to make that, maybe do even better. Television prices may be lower, but manufacturers have to put glass on all of them.   Hickey: Pacific Media came out with a forecast on flat-panel TV sales about a month ago. They see a 42% increase in last year's revenue, but their revenue-growth forecast is zero for this year. That feeds back to all the suppliers. They're going to force Corning's glass sales down. I heard a great line last month in a conference call: There's no nourishment in a bowlful of volume. That was from one of the big retailers, talking about flat-panel TVs.   MacAllaster: So sales will come down some. But TVs still need glass.   Gabelli: Also, Corning is finally laying optical fiber again.   MacAllaster: I've got one more name: Pioneer Natural Resources [PXD]. It trades on the Big Board. Book value is $16 a share. It costs them about $8 to find a barrel of oil. Most other producers have a $10 to $12 cost. The stock's high was 54.40 last year, and the low was 36.43. It trades around 38 now. Pioneer pays a small dividend of 26 cents a share, but it's a cash-flow story. The company sold forward a lot of its production and got lower prices for it, but used the money to buy back shares. They reduced the capitalization from 145 million shares to 125 million, and are on their way to 100 million.   A lot of the forward sales are coming off now. They should earn about $2 to $2.05 a share for 2006, and $3.50 to $3.60 for this year. They increased reserves 10% last year, and think they can do this for another three to four years. Pioneer is the third-largest independent oil and gas producer in the U.S. They have sold off some foreign assets and put the money in the U.S. Exploration results have been excellent. Capital spending was about $270 million over the past two years. That's about 12 bucks a share per year.   Black: Actually, until recently they had bad luck drilling reserves. One of the hedge funds [Highfields Capital Management] took a big stake and shook up management. It's possible this one's going to be put in play.   Gabelli: If it helps them find oil, that's good.   MacAllaster: They've got a lot of it. My stock-price target is 55, up from 38 now. You've got a good chance with this.     Barron's: Thanks for those ideas, Archie. Let's hear from Abby.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) Rich America, Poor America -2-
Story: Gap's (GPS) Banana Republic currently is heavily promoting a line of handbags that the retailer touts as the new "it" bags. The company's online home page last week featured some of the bags that resembled many Coach creations.   Can this sort of merchandising work? Hurley thinks mid-tier companies like Banana Republic will have a hard time commanding prices anywhere near those that premium brands enjoy.   Indeed, the net losers in the new world of Plutonomy are mass-market brands. Their core customers aren't enjoying much of an increase in income, while their home equity has slipped and they're being squeezed by inflation, albeit it mild, in necessities.   For every Target (TGT) that has had some success in wooing the style-conscious with clever store and product design, there is a Wal-Mart (WMT) that stumbles trying. Middle-of-the-road department stores such as J.C. Penney (JCP) and Kohl's (KSS) have had good runs, sprucing up product lines for those of moderate incomes, but the headwinds will turn brisk if the income concentration story plays on.   Yet this winner-take-most setup doesn't mean that the stock market will only reward companies that ply the most posh ZIP codes. There are several stock plays on the cash-strapped consumer.   Richard Bernstein, strategist at Merrill Lynch, said last month that dollar stores were an under-appreciated group that would be a big beneficiary of lower energy prices in 2007. So far, these lower fuel costs have arrived in a dramatic way. If, indeed, real wage growth turns positive in a tight labor market in the latter stages of a profit cycle -- as many now predict -- then the dollar stores could get even more of a lift. Stocks of companies like Family Dollar (FDO) and Big Lots (BIG) have been perky in recent months.   Obvious losers as many lower-income consumers become over-extended are subprime lenders, several of which have already filed for bankruptcy protection while others have seen their shares walloped.   In a dimmer corner of the financial industry sit pawn shops and payday lenders, which are thriving. Stephanie Pomboy of MacroMavens has been cited more than once in Barron's targeting these lenders of last resort as a play on the housing bust.   EZCorp (EZPW) and First Cash Financial (FCFS) are winners here. Be warned, however, that regulatory and legislative rumblings are emerging that would crack down on the practices of payday lenders, which many view as predators on the poor.     Kapur's Plutonomy theory also helps make sense of what appear superficially to be some disconnects in the economic data.   For instance, it has become popular among some Wall Street economists to marvel at the abiding growth in overall consumer spending, even as gasoline prices spiked in 2005, as housing turnover collapsed last year, and as consumer-confidence surveys have periodically dipped to dour levels. The simple fact is that the swollen incomes and investment accounts of the top several percent of households can drive an awful lot of spending.   The $16.5 billion that Goldman Sachs (GS) paid its employees last year makes up for an awful lot of wage stagnation elsewhere. Multiply that by all the other beneficiaries of the asset-economy boom -- merger lawyers, hedge-fund impresarios and art dealers -- and it helps explain why broad consumption figures defy the democratically sampled surveys of consumer confidence. It's a phenomenon that many find uncomfortable, but it's a fact.   Barron's economics editor Gene Epstein points out that many economists focus on the government's disposable personal income figures to divine the public's spending power.   But this number is strongly influenced, quarter to quarter, by "factors affecting the wealthy, such as fluctuations in investment income and the change in the tax take due to more people moving into high brackets during an expansion. And since consumer spending by the wealthy is generally impervious to income, that explains why DPI is a far less useful number than wages and salaries in explaining consumer spending," he maintains.   Similar technical factors involving capital gains among the wealthy also serve to depress the national savings rate, often rendering it negative. While most households, it's true, fail to save much, if anything, the country is producing a sizable nest egg.   Kapur invokes the fast-expanding ratio of wealthy citizens' net worth to income. This has allowed them to spend more quickly than income rises. To some degree this is rational, and bodes well for the continuance of high-end consumption.     This is not to suggest that the economy can thrive indefinitely with an ever-widening income gulf, especially if the earnings of those at the median point or below stagnate or backslide for any stretch of time.   And, as anyone who watches cable news or reads the papers can affirm, the conspicuous divide between the often overindulgent rich and the struggling average worker has become a potent -- and potentially explosive -- political and social issue.   Several members of Congress were elected last year on sharply populist positions. Former Sen. John Edwards, a North Carolina Democrat, is readying his 2008 presidential bid on his tested theme of "Two Americas." And some media personalities are forging lucrative careers decrying outsourcing and scapegoating immigrants.   The outrage among the public and in Washington about executive-pay deals of the sort that handed Robert Nardelli $210 million for departing as Home Depot (HD) CEO will spur congressional hearings and possibly legislation before long.   While the notion of the estate tax remains unpopular in polls, even though just a tiny fraction of Americans will ever be subject to it, chances of repeal have dimmed.   History has shown that Americans, more than most of their counterparts around the world, favor equality of opportunity but shun measures to actively redistribute income. They choose to preserve the possibility of outsized rewards, so long as they believe a decent proportion of society has a legitimate shot at winning them.   Still, when the pie is being cut as unevenly as it is now, support grows for bolstering labor's slice of economic rewards. This may lead to more egalitarian measures and perhaps have a shaming effect on, say, corporate board members determining how much to pay a new chief executive.   Overseas, authoritarian or socialist governments might well be moved to target the hyper-rich of their countries or foreign interests who have hit the globalization jackpot. Who knows what a Hugo Chavez is contemplating?   There's little evidence to suggest that any likely measures will derail the long-lived emergence of an ever-richer tier of achievers, entertainers, asset-mediators and inheritors. But it's clear that the world of Plutonomy is creating dangers as well as opportunities as it evolves.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(1/20) Google's Next Ad Gambit May Be Inside Videogames
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Nick Wingfield and Kevin J. Delaney   Google Inc.'s efforts to broker advertisements beyond the Web could soon expand into ads that appear in videogames.   The Mountain View, Calif., company is in talks to acquire Adscape Media Inc., a closely held San Francisco company whose technology allows for the delivery of advertising over the Internet and placement within videogames, according to people familiar with the matter. They added that a deal could be reached as early as next week.   While the possible terms of a deal aren't known, Microsoft Corp. last year acquired Massive Inc., a company that delivers in-game ads, for close to $200 million.   An acquisition of Adscape, if completed, would allow Google to offer the hundreds of thousands of advertisers who currently buy online ads through its system to also buy ads that appear within videogames. The market for delivering ads into games -- such as a virtual billboard on a racetrack or a poster in a boxing arena -- is still in its infancy, but major games publishers such as Electronic Arts Inc. believe it could be a lucrative business and many are pursuing it aggressively. Sending ads over the Internet is just now becoming more feasible through new game consoles such as Sony Corp.'s PlayStation 3 and Microsoft's Xbox 360, which are designed to be connected to the Internet.   One person familiar with the matter says Google for months has been discussing with game publishers the prospect of delivering ads over the Internet into the action of their games.   If completed, a deal with Adscape would form part of an ambitious Google effort to broker advertising across many types of media globally. The Internet company, whose 2006 revenue is expected to top $10 billion on the strength of its online-ad sales, currently is testing systems for selling ads in newspapers and on radio, and has said it plans to extend into television ads. People familiar with the matter say it is discussing a possible agreement with CBS Corp. that would include brokering TV and radio advertisements. Both CBS and Google have declined to comment on any talks.   A Google spokesman declined to comment on any talks with Adscape, saying "We are always considering new ways to extend Google's advertising program to benefit our users, advertisers and publishers. In-game advertising offers one such possible extension among many others."   Adscape Chairman Bernard Stolar said he "has spoken to every major player" about a possible acquisition of Adscape, but there currently is no such deal.   People familiar with the matter say Google had looked at Massive prior to Microsoft's acquisition of the company. A purchase of Adscape would add a new front to expanding competition between Google and Microsoft, which today stretches from Web search to word processing. Google could look to form an alliance with Microsoft's archrival in the games console business, Sony.   In-game advertising has attracted an array of contenders, including IGA Worldwide Inc. and Double Fusion Inc. Adscape's chairman Mr. Stolar is a well-connected veteran of the games business, having previously served as an executive at Sega, Sony's U.S. games division and Atari, and could help Google form crucial partnerships with publishers.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:00 ET (05:00 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : Musiwave Secures Exclusive on New Shakira Ringtone
Story: Established Recording Industry Relationships Provide Added Value to Musiwave's Operator Customers       REDWOOD CITY, Calif. and MIDEM, CANNES, France, Jan. 20 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ -- Musiwave, an Openwave company (Openwave Systems Inc. Nasdaq: OPWV), and a leading provider of mobile music entertainment services to operators and media companies worldwide, today announced at MIDEM 2007 an exclusive arrangement with SonyBMG for the new ringtone of Shakira's unreleased, "Pure Intuition." Exclusive distribution coincides with the launch of her 2007 Shakira "Oral Fixation" European tour on January 25. The ringtone, ringback tone and full track will be sold through Musiwave operator partners worldwide and through Musiwave-branded online portals. An end-to-end service provider, Musiwave offers mobile operators hosted content, programming, and innovative content exclusives.     "We are delighted to be again working with SONY BMG to bring the hottest exclusive offers to our customers," said Albin Serviant, senior director of marketing for Musiwave. "Our ability to provide our customers with exclusive access to exciting new content like the "Pure Intuition" ringtone speaks to the strength of our relationships with labels like SonyBMG and bring value not only to the label but the artist and our operator partners as well."     Musiwave provides mobile music entertainment services to over 35 mobile operators in 25 countries including Vodafone, T-Mobile, Telefonica, Orange, SFR, TELUS and Amena. Musiwave's current roster of products includes Music on Demand Service (MODS(TM)), a full track mobile music subscription offering which allows fast, full-length secure downloads of music directly to 3G mobile devices; Smart Radio, an interactive and personalized streaming radio solution; and Music Wizard(TM), which enables users to identify a song in just a few seconds using their mobile phone.        About Musiwave and Openwave     Musiwave, an Openwave company (Openwave Systems Inc. Nasdaq: OPWV), is a leading provider of mobile music entertainment solutions, including software, marketing and content management, to operators and media companies worldwide. For more information, please visit www.musiwave.net. Openwave Systems Inc. (Nasdaq: OPWV) is the leading independent provider of software solutions that ignite mobility for the communications and media industries. Openwave empowers its customers to rapidly transform their business by sparking new revenue streams and market opportunities, building loyal subscriber communities and reducing operational costs. Openwave's broad range of IP-based handset-to- network solutions enable the rapid launch of information, communication and entertainment services across networks and devices and include handset software, content delivery, adaptive messaging, location, music and video services. Openwave is a global company headquartered in Redwood City, California. For more information please visit www.openwave.com.     NOTE:  Openwave and the Musiwave logo are trademarks of Openwave Systems Inc.  All other trademarks are the properties of their respective owners.    SOURCE  Openwave Systems Inc.       /CONTACT: Trisha Mirel, Public Relations of Openwave Systems Inc., +1-650-480-5509, or trisha.mirel@openwave.com      /Web site: http://www.openwave.com/     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 04:00 ET (09:00 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(1/22) Rich America, Poor America
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Michael Santoli   Twenty-five apartments in Manhattan sold for more than $20 million in 2005, up from five in 2004, with a few fetching $40 million-plus. NetJets couldn't meet the enormous demand for its private-jet flights over the Thanksgiving holiday. Imports of French cognac into China surged 24% in 2006. And, last May, an unidentified Russian bought Dora Maar with Cat for $95 million, the second-highest price ever for a Picasso.   Never in history have the haves had so much. Burgeoning wealth and incomes from globalizing industries, swelling asset markets, media ubiquity and fast-developing emerging economies are accruing disproportionately to the entrepreneur class and the already rich. This is giving the world's affluent a greater capacity to splurge, build, invest and gamble than ever before.   Those of lesser means in the developed economies are suffering or stagnating financially by comparison, though in absolute terms standards of living are holding up or advancing modestly. Thus do we see the expanding "wealth gap" that populist politicians bemoan, capitalists celebrate and editorialists puzzle over. While there are some aspects of the income-and-wealth divergence that can be explained by cyclical forces, the long-term pattern in which the rich get rapidly richer seems durable. And there remain exploitable investment opportunities tied to this trend.   The numerical evidence is plentiful, thanks to data collectors who want to reverse the trend or take advantage of it. For years, both the number of wealthy households and their aggregate resources have been growing much faster then world gross domestic product. The latest Merrill Lynch-CapGemini World Wealth Report estimates that the number of people globally with financial assets exceeding $1 million climbed 6.5% in 2005, and their combined financial wealth rose 8.5%, to $33.3 trillion, for an average of $3.8 million each. It's getting to the point where "millionaire" will no longer serve as useful shorthand for defining who's rich.     The financial net worth of this segment grew 20% in North America, 23% in Latin America, 50% in the Middle East, 15% in Asia and 9% in Europe.   In the U.S., according to the liberal think tank Economic Policy Institute, the richest 1% of Americans had net wealth 190 times that of the median household, up from a ratio of 168 in 1998 and 131 in 1983. The top 1% owned 37% of all domestic stocks held by individuals in 2004, and the top 10% owned 79% of all stock. The real income of the richest 5% of U.S. residents climbed an aggregate 31% from 1985 through 2004, versus 14% for the middle 20% and 12% for the bottom 20%.   Though academics continue to seek definitive causes for this widening of the wealth divide (see "Wealth Inequality: Data and Models," www.nber.org/papers/ w12550) several forces clearly seem to contribute to it.   The income premium on higher education has grown in recent years, as the economy became more service-based and rewarded those with better communication, organizational and creative skills. And educated folks have gotten better at passing on educational and economic advantages to their children, while those lacking education have fewer reliable, good-paying manufacturing jobs available to them. This contributes to a winner-take-most economy, with slight inflation-adjusted declines in the median household income in recent years.   The opening of world economies to competitive forces and capitalist incentives has allowed innovative people to access deep global financial markets. Lower tax rates on capital in the U.S. and elsewhere obviously have played a role, as well.   With technology allowing cheap global communication, information and entertainment products can easily reach a vastly larger audience than ever before. Economists have long theorized that technology would help create a class of super-rich celebrities.   Tom Cruise is worth what he is because his movies can address markets numbering billions. Satellite TV has meant that English soccer star David Beckham could go from a team in Manchester to one in Madrid to, this month, one in Los Angeles, where he was given a $250 million, five-year contract and will be watched by sports fans in Europe, Africa, Latin America and Fresno.     From a cyclical angle, the percentage of U.S. GDP now attributable to corporate profits is near a multi-decade high. These profits are driven by global demand and fast productivity gains. They drive strong dividend and capital-gains income toward the affluent, while restraining wage growth. UBS points out that prior profit cycles also have seen the median wage stagnate until the middle of an economic expansion, after which it gains some ground.   Finally, this wealth buildup has created plenty of well-paying jobs in the asset-churning professions. The American service economy is commonly thought of as relying on fast-food soda jerks and hair stylists. But among America's key exports is that investment banker in the Upper Class section of a Virgin Atlantic flight to London, preparing to cut a billion-dollar deal.   Ajay Kapur, global strategist at Citigroup, has been bundling these economic trends into a theme that he calls Plutonomy -- a global economy disproportionately propelled by the rich. To Kapur, the pattern of rapid and lopsided wealth buildup around the world is a durable one.   "The spread of free financial markets, patent protection and the rule of law," he says, means that more smart, ambitious people than ever are able to turn a good idea into capital, and capital into liquid wealth.   Indeed, Kapur disagrees with the popular idea that the current high share of corporate profits in the developed economies -- which tends to be funneled into the pockets of the rich and of business owners -- will ebb toward historical norms.   "To me, the profit share of GDP will get even higher, back to the (record) levels of the '50s," he says. Then, the arms buildup for the world wars spurred a long period of innovation and wealth accumulation, and the broken economies of Japan and Germany were rebuilt. Today, Kapur suggests, we are still reaping the benefits of Cold War spending, while financing the rapid expansion of China and India.   The spending power of the rich has grown so formidable and shows so few signs of reversing, investors probably still have an opportunity to harness this dynamic in their portfolios.   Citigroup, among other firms, has assembled a basket of stocks that should benefit from the Plutonomy thesis. Luxury-goods stocks have outperformed the market for more than a decade, so the market has to some degree sussed out the macro forces. Yet in many ways the backdrop remains favorable for the sector.   The Citi basket includes 24 names, including Coach (COH); Sotheby's (BID); Polo Ralph Lauren (RL); Tiffany (TIF); Four Seasons Hotels (FS) and, from Europe and Asia, Bulgari (BUL.Italy); Burberry (BRBY.UK); Mandarin Oriental (MAND. Singapore); Julius Baer (BAER.Switzerland); LVMH (MC.France); Porsche (POR3.Germany) and Shangri-La Asia (69.Hong Kong).   As noted, stocks of this ilk already have outpaced the broad market over recent years. And, on average, they carry higher valuations than the broad indexes. Still they haven't left the rest of the market in their wake. In the past year or so, this portfolio has merely kept pace with the global markets, Kapur notes.     He thinks that these stocks tend to hit their stride for outperformance in periods when equities are doing better than housing in the asset-class race. That, certainly, began to occur last year and could well continue for some time. He adds that, in the past, the relative valuation of the luxury group hasn't prevented it from delivering superior returns.   UBS strategist Tom Doerflinger last year put together a similar list, though this one geared toward companies with a strong franchise in selling to the affluent in the States. It includes such stalwarts as American Express (AXP); Best Buy (BBY); Constellation Brands (STZ); Merrill Lynch (MER); Nordstrom (JWN); Simon Property Group (SPG); Starbucks (SBUX) and Whole Foods Market (WFMI).   A distinguishing strength of luxury companies is their brands' enduring power, which transcends time, country and culture. Doerflinger notes that Louis Vuitton and Tiffany trace their history to the 19th century.   Because of their exclusivity -- real or imputed -- and the lack of price sensitivity of their core customers, these brands have enviable pricing power. Says James Hurley, who follows the luxury sector for Telsey Advisory Group in New York: "I expect we'll continue to hear about sustained momentum" in these businesses. "We have price increases coming our way soon" from European luxe specialists, inspired by strong demand and the greenback's decline last year versus the euro. That will provide a pricing umbrella for domestic competitors such as Coach and Tiffany, who will "go along for the ride."   The best of these brands manage both to maintain their prestige at the high end and to broaden their base with entry-level items. Tiffany's $100 "Return to Tiffany" dog-tag charm necklaces and Coach's colorful $88 iPod covers do the trick.   In the market for consumables, newly well-off people in emerging economies grasp for Western brands that attest to success and disposable income. Starbucks has proven quite exportable, and European liquor companies are duking it out in the burgeoning Chinese cognac market.     The brand power of the luxury nameplates presents a tremendous challenge to more mainstream purveyors trying to gain a foothold in the wallets of the well-off.   "For mid-market brands trying to trade up, it's easier said than done," Hurley observes. "Just go to the department stores and see what's marked down." As an example, he points to the singer Gwen Stefani's handbags, listed at $300 to $600, as "markdowns waiting to happen."   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UPDATE:India ICICI Bk 3Q Net Up 42% On Strong Loan Demand
Story: (Updates with company, analyst comments, background)     MUMBAI (Dow Jones)--ICICI Bank Ltd. (532174.BY), India's second-largest bank by assets, Saturday said its fiscal third-quarter net profit rose 42% on-year on the back of strong demand for loans, and added that it doesn't expect rising interest rates to slow credit growth.   Net profit for the quarter ended Dec. 31, 2006, rose to INR9.10 billion ($205.5 million), from INR6.40 billion a year earlier, beating expectations. The averaged estimates from a Dow Jones Newswires poll of six analysts forecast a net profit of INR8.16 billion.   "This has again been a strong quarter for the bank. I expected about a 28%-29% growth in PAT, but 42% is totally unexpected," said Sarika Lohra, an analyst at Mumbai-based brokerage Angel Broking.   ICICI Bank Joint Managing Director Kalpana Morparia attributed the growth to the 32% on-year increase in net interest income and a growth in fee income.   The New York-listed bank's quarterly net interest income, the difference between interest earned and interest paid,  increased to INR17.09 billion, from INR12.96 billion a year earlier, driven by total asset growth of over 39%% and a net interest margin, or NIM, of 2.6%. The NIM expanded from 2.5% in the second quarter.   For the quarter, total advances grew 41% to INR1,727.63 billion from INR1226.13 billion a year earlier, led by demand for retail loans, both domestic as well as international, said Morparia.   "We have not seen any slowdown in disbursements which would give us a cause to say that it won't increase," said Morparia. "Overall, for the system credit growth that people are talking about of 30%, we certainly believe the system will be very close to that."   Lohra however said that customers have a "limited repayment capacity and any further rate hikes will definitely hurt credit demand."   "Last year, ICICI reported an overall credit growth of about 50%. This year, it has already slowed down to about 43%. I expect the growth to slow to about 35%-40% for the full year (ending March 31)," she added.   She, however, expects the bank, which has a customer base of 22 million, to grow its net interest income on the back rising low cost deposits.   Deposits grew 47% on-year and of that, 75% came from the low-cost from retail banking space, said Lohra.   Morparia expects the bank to maintain NIM at current levels.   For ICICI Bank, retail assets constituted 68% of total advances and 65% of customer assets, the bank said in a statement. The bank has a 32% share of the retail loan market in India.   Banks such as ICICI Bank and HDFC Bank Ltd. (500180.BY) have benefited from India's booming economy, which grew 9.2% in the second quarter of the current fiscal year and is expected to grow at 8% for the full year. India's fiscal year runs from April to March.   Demand for credit has kept pace with the growing overall conomy, with around 30% growth on average each of the past three years - underscoring the need for funds from the housing and industrial sectors, as well as a rise in consumer-credit demand from an increasingly affluent middle class.   HDFC Bank, which has a strong presence in the retail lending market, earlier in the month posted a 32% growth in its net profit for the fiscal third quarter, spurred by a rise in interest income, and had said it expects growth to be stable despite rising interest rates.   Morparia expects the Reserve Bank of India to hike its key short term rates at its meeting Jan 31.   "Given the way inflation numbers are coming in, I wouldn't rule out a rate hike," she said.   She expects a combination of higher interest rates and rising real estates prices to slow demand for home loans.   "Disbursements have been relatively muted for the last nine months as compared to the previous nine months. Earlier, we were talking about a growth of 30%-35%, now we are talking about 25% to 30%," she said.   The bank's quarterly fee income increased 53% to INR13.45 billion from INR8.81 billion a year earlier.   "The retail business, which includes the credit related fees, and the third party distribution, contributed about 57% of the fee income. The corporate banks contributed 27%, and about 13% was contributed by our international branches," said Morparia.   The bank plans to open 110 new branches by early February, Morparia said. "And once the merger with Sangli Bank comes through, we'll add 200 more branches."     -By Romit Guha; Dow Jones Newswires; 91-9900181471; romit.guha@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 05:23 ET (10:23 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Indie Record Labels Pool Catalog In Challenge To Majors
Story: CANNES, France (AP)--Independent record labels behind artists like The White Stripes, Deep Purple and Arctic Monkeys announced a global deal Saturday to pool access to their catalogs, seeking to grab a bigger share of online music sales from the major record companies.   Indies and their trade groups from more than a dozen countries signed up to Merlin, a nonprofit licensing agency that will cut deals on their behalf with download sites under the terms of the agreement unveiled at Midem, a music industry gathering in the French Riviera town of Cannes.   Smaller record companies with just a handful of successful artists fear being left behind in fast-growing digital music markets, where the majors - Universal Music Group, Sony Corp. (SNE)-Bertelsmann AG joing venture Sony BMG, EMI Group PLC (EMI.LN) and Warner Music Group Corp. (WMG) - enjoy a clear advantage in negotiations with online retailers such as Napster and Apple Computer Inc.'s (AAPL) iTunes.   "Merlin may be the most important move we as independents will ever undertake to secure our mutual prosperity in this rapidly changing business landscape," said Brett Gurewitz, owner of U.S.-based Epitaph Records, whose artists include Tom Waits.   Indie labels account for about 80% of new music releases in major markets but only 30% of total revenues, according to industry data for 2005, partly because the majors spend more on marketing and have - until recently - maintained tight control over distribution channels.   That is already changing with the inexorable rise of online sales, analysts say, as more artists achieve success and celebrity through independent record companies, bypassing the top four.   "While you don't get the benefit of their marketing capabilities, the reality is that the majority of good new music being adopted by younger people is mostly spread through social networking and personal recommendations," said Tim Bajarin, president of California-based consulting firm Creative Strategies.   "The indies are where we see some of the fastest growth in the next generation of music adoption," he said.   Billed as a "one-stop licensing shop," Merlin will allow download sites and other digital platforms to access its members' music in one deal, rather than the thousands of separate contracts they would otherwise have to negotiate.   Martin Mills, chairman of The Beggars Group - which produces Basement Jaxx, The White Stripes and the Pixies - said the new Netherlands-based agency would create a "virtual fifth major" from its combined catalog. "Merlin will license collectively the individually unlicensable," he said.   The scheme is backed by indie labels and associations from countries including Australia, Brazil, the U.K., Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Israel, Japan, New Zealand, South Africa, Spain, Sweden and the U.S.   According to Ted Schadler, an analyst with U.S.-based Forrester Research, the licensing deal could alter the balance of power within the music industry. Providing it's backed up with efficient management of payments and distribution, it would make it viable for even the smallest labels to sell music through mainstream sites by removing the cost of negotiating and managing an individual contract with each one.   "What this does is level the playing field between indies and majors," Schadler said.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 07:44 ET (12:44 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) 2007 Barron's Roundtable -- Part -6-
Story: My next recommendation is Petroleo Brasileiro, or Petrobras [PBR], the Brazilian oil company. The case for higher oil prices during the rest of this decade remains valid, based on continued industrialization and rising living standards in emerging economies, which will lead to higher demand. On the supply side, the depletion rate in existing fields is roughly 4% per year, and oil companies face increasing difficulties replacing production with new reserves. The structural tightness has developed over 20 years, and it won't go away soon. Now we see only a temporary softness due to a slowing economy, better weather and such. Oil prices this year may come down to the $50-a-barrel level, or lower, but they won't stay down. Exploration, production and servicing will continue to boom, and profit margins will stay high. I still expect the price of oil to be at $100 or higher by the end of this decade.     Barron's: Why Petrobras?   Zulauf: It is the seventh largest integrated oil company in the world. It operates primarily in Brazil and other parts of Latin America, but is diversifying into North America and Europe. Petrobras was established in 1953 as a Brazilian state enterprise with a monopoly in Brazil. In recent years a gradual deregulation and privatization program took effect in Brazil, and price controls were eliminated fully in 2002. In 2000 the government sold 153 million of the company's 634 million common shares in the form of ADRs [American depositary receipts].   Petrobras plans to grow production by 7% to 8% in the next five years. It is active off the coast of Brazil, where it expects to increase production. On the one hand it is an integrated oil company operating successfully. On the other, you get exposure to an emerging economy and market. Interest rates are still high in Brazil but coming down. There is a long way to go before they are normalized. At the last peak, in 2000, earnings hit $4.92 a share. In 2002 they bottomed at $2.13. In 2005 Petrobras earned $9 per share, and the consensus for '06 is $11.50. Consensus estimates are virtually the same for 2007, as analysts are cautious. The stock trades for 8.5 times earnings, and is one of the cheapest, if not the cheapest, major oil stocks. The dividend yield is 3.8%. I would buy into a serious market shakeout. The shares could decline from today's 95 to 80 or so in the next few months.     Barron's: Isn't there political risk in Brazil?   Zulauf: There is always that risk in Latin America, but it is relatively low here. Brazil opened up its economy just a few years ago. The high on the stock was 107 in May, and the low was 69 in June. I see a similar correction coming, though the stock could double by the end of the decade.   My last pick is a Norwegian fertilizer company, Yara International [YAR.Norway.] The world population keeps growing, and a big part of it is getting wealthier, which is changing the way people feed themselves. A few years ago, I pointed to extremely depressed inventory levels in the grains. The inventory-consumption ratio in wheat is at a new 25-year low. Fertilizer companies sold 10% less fertilizer for last year's planting season, due to the fact that farmers' income was squeezed by rising energy prices and low grain prices. But a drought in Australia cut the harvest in half, and wheat prices rose sharply. Since midyear, grain prices have risen by more than 40%, energy prices are lower and farmers' income is improving. I expect fertilizer sales to go up for the new planting season.     Barron's: Tell us more about Yara.   Zulauf: In the past I recommended Potash Corp. of Saskatchewan [POT] and Kali und Salz, or K+S [SDF..Germany], which are still prime choices. So is Yara, which was spun out of Norsk Hydro [NHY] in 2004, at 41 Norwegian kroner. Yara produces and markets mineral fertilizer, which accounts for about 90% of sales. Gas and chemicals account for the rest. Its products include standard nitrogen fertilizers, and complex nitrogen, phosphate and potassium fertilizers. In contrast to Potash, whose fertilizer is mined, Yara's is based on natural gas, so there's a little more risk in the stock.   Yara operates worldwide, though its principal markets are Europe, North America and Brazil. The company employs 7,000 people. It has about $8 billion of sales. Yara should be a major beneficiary of rising grain prices, and will be able to sell more fertilizer. The stock trades in Norway for NOK137.50.   Black: It also trades over the counter in the U.S., under the ticker YARIY.   Zulauf: In Norway, the stock trades for NOK137. The company earned NOK8.95 in 2004 and NOK10.20 in '05. NOK10.70 is the consensus estimate for '06, and NOK11.70 is the estimate for 2007, though actual results could be a lot higher. The stock sells for 11 to 12 times earnings and yields 1.7%. The dividend is NOK2.35. This stock also has to correct first, maybe by 10%, to get to where I'd would want to buy it.     Barron's: Thank you, Felix. John, are you ready?   Neff: Picking up on Lyondell, I'm estimating $4.75 a share in '07 earnings, so the stock sells at an astronomical price-earnings multiple of 5.2. As you know, instead of selling its share of the refinery it owned in conjunction with the Republic of Venezuela, Lyondell bought Venezuela's 41% stake and turned a balance sheet that was starting to improve into one that is very leveraged now. The refinery in the Houston Ship Channel amounts to about half their earnings, or $2.35 a share, pro forma. They're a substantial chemical company. They saw a bit of deterioration in the fourth quarter in their principal chemical, the so-called ethylene chain, but it's starting to come back. I've got them earning 90 cents to a dollar a share in the quarter.   In the first quarter of this year their refinery is going down for two weeks. This is a turnaround they have to do every 18-24 months to keep it in good shape. [Last week Lyondell announced a major refinery overhaul of the sort it performs every 5-6 years. As a result, John now expects the company to earn $4.50 in 2007.]for the full year.]     Barron's: And the rest of the year?   Neff: In the last three quarters of '07 they should be going full blast. The chemcial business was spun out of Atlantic Richfield about 20 years ago. It uses as feedstock a high-sulfur oil, which sells at a considerable discount to sweet crude. By the third and fourth quarter, gross margins will run at about $14-$15 a barrel. Sweet-crude margins are around $4 a barrel so you can see why this is a good entity. It's the eighth-largest refinery in the country. They paid $2.1 billion for Venezuela's interest, but got a better crude price from Venezuela.   MacAllaster: For five years. They have a five-year contract.   Neff: Lyondell yields 3.6%, and pays a 90-cent dividend. It will pay back $1.5 billion of debt in the next few years. The company will be investment-grade maybe two or three years out, so they can do something with the dividend or buy back stock.     Barron's: What is your target?   Neff: It's 40, which would be up 60% from the current price. As far as 2008 earnings go, they won't have a turnaround at the refinery -- you do that every two years -- so they'll make more in the quarter. If they pay down that debt, interest costs will fall by about 30 cents a share. Add them up and you've got 60 cents in hand, no matter what happens on the other fronts. They're locked in the candy store, and will earn $5.30 to $5.50 in '08.   One caveat is refinery accidents, but that's one reason for the turnaround -- to make sure everything is working.     Barron's: What is your next stock?   Neff: Nabors Industries [NBR], the largest land driller in the world. It operates in North America, including Canada, but also offshore. It is not nearly as concentrated as some others. Natural-gas prices have gonethe wrong way recently, so the stock has fallen from 41 to 28.55. I've got them earning $4.60 a share this year, which makes for another astronomical P/E.     Barron's: On what price gas?   Neff: Maybe prices go a little higher than today's $6 per mcf or so. The futures contract for '08 is $8 per mcf. This is a coward's way to bet on natural gas, which, after all, is a clean fuel. Nabors is in a good position to punch more holes in the ground. You can buy all this at 6.2 times earnings.   Zuluaf: Right now, there is too much natural gas.   Neff: No, there is too little use of natural gas. I predict that before this winter is over, it will get cold. [Touche, John. Temperatures dropped below freezing in the Northeast last week.]   MacAllaster: You only have to go back a few years, and natural gas was $2.50 per mcf. It flipped to $10. It went back to $4. It's very volatile, so $6 isn't a bad price.   Black: I own Nabors, as well. The CEO, Gene Isenberg, is getting on in years. There is an issue of successorship. The company also is selling for about six times enterprise value to Ebitda [earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization.] It could be vulnerable to a private-equity deal.   Samberg: These things'll all be gone.   Neff: My third recommendation is YRC Worldwide [YRCW], the old Yellow Freight. With Roadway Express and U.S. Freight they put together a tasty morsel, but it hasn't done well in the market. I've got them earning an aggressive $5.75 in 2007. It's 6.8 times earnings. Notice that all my stocks have a very low multiple. All of them could be candidates for buyouts.     Barron's: That's the biggest attraction, right?   Samberg: That's the common thread.   Neff: Obviously, Lyondell has a lot of debt. The other two, Nabors and YRC, are not that bad, though there is a question in YRC's case about pension obligations. The company has done a good job integrating Roadway and U.S. Freight, and it will do more acquisitions. It is capitalized at just over $2 billion. In the past year, two quarters were bad, because Wal-Mart [WMT] and the like cut their inventories. Fourth-quarter earnings were marked down from about $1.50 to maybe $1-$1.10. What do you think trucking tonnage was down by in November?   MacAllaster: Nine percent.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS:UBS Moves To Woo Potential Aston Martin Bidders
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--UBS AG (UBS), the investment bank handling the sale of Ford Motor Co. (F) luxury unit Aston Martin, is understood to be drafting last-minute business plans to dissuade potential bidders from walking away from the auction of the division, The Times of London reported Saturday, quoting sources close to the situation.   The move comes amid growing dissatisfaction among potential bidders, who are understood to include Permira and the Doughty Hanson Consortium, who say that they have found items in Aston Martin's books that will force them to reduce potential bids for the unit, the Times reported.   Quoting sources close to the situation, the Times reported that the potential bidders have been instructed to submit offers of more than GBP450 million to advance to the auction's second round.   However, due diligence conducted by the potential bidders has revealed a pensions deficit of about GBP7 million relating to Jaguar employees seconded to Aston Martin, as well as car perks to certain employees that will cost the the unit's new owner between GBP3 million and GBP4 million.   The Times reported that the sources say UBS is likely to postpone the date for final bids, which had been set for Jan. 31, to give potential new bidders sufficient time to meet Aston Martin's management.   The Times report didn't include an official response from U.S. auto giant Ford, which took a controlling stake in Aston Martin in 1987 but last year decided to sell the unit as part of a restructuring.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 07:17 ET (12:17 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS: Smiths Plans To Pursue JVs After GBP2.5B GE Deal
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Smiths Group PLC (SMIN.LN) is planning to spend up to GBP500 million this year expanding its medical and engineering divisions in the hopes of emulating the deal it did with General Electric Co.
