(GE) last week, in which it sold its aerospace unit for GBP2.5 billion and formed a joint venture in its detection business, the Times of London reported Saturday.   Quoting Smiths chief executive Keith Butler-Wheelhouse, the Times reported that Smiths' medical business, which makes anesthesia equipment and John Crane, which makes mechanical seals, are possible candidates for growth and divestment.   Although about GBP2.1 billion of the money raised from the GE sale will be returned to shareholders, the loss of the capital intensive aerospace business will allow the company to carry more debt and this in turn would free up Smiths to spend GBP400 million to GBP500 million on acquisitions, the Times reported.     Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk     -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 07:16 ET (12:16 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: : WSB Financial Group, Inc. Appoints New Director
Story: BREMERTON, Wash., Jan. 20 /PRNewswire-FirstCall/ - WSB Financial Group, Inc. (Nasdaq: WSFG), the bank holding company for Westsound Bank, announced today that Donald F. Cox, CPA, has been appointed to its Board of Directors on January 16, 2007. Cox, 54, is a principal of Cox & Lucy, a public accounting firm in Port Orchard, Washington. He has been in private practice as an accountant since 1976.        About WSB Financial Group, Inc.     WSB is a bank holding company headquartered in Bremerton, Washington. Its subsidiary, Westsound Bank, operates eight full service branches and two loan production offices in the west Puget Sound area of Washington.    SOURCE  WSB Financial Group, Inc.       /CONTACT: David K. Johnson, President and CEO of WSB Financial Group, Inc., +1-360-475-9374     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 11:00 ET (16:00 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(1/22) Follow-Up: For Symantec, A Lingering Virus
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   The naysayers may have been right. Symantec has yet to prove the wisdom of its controversial 2005 acquisition of Veritas Software, a maker of enterprise back-up software.   Symantec, known for its anti-virus software, last week lowered its profit projections for its fiscal third quarter, ended in December, to 10-11 cents a share, down from a previous forecast of 14-15 cents.   The Cupertino, Calif., company, with a market value of $16.4 billion, also slashed fiscal 2007 profit estimates to no higher than 39 cents a share from a range of up to 56 cents a share. The stock plunged about 13% on the pre-announcement to 17.79, then dropped to 17.54 by Friday.   Result: The shares are about 5% below where they were trading when we ran a favorable story on the company last fall ("The Best Defense," Sept. 11, 2006). At the time, we postulated that Symantec Chief Executive John Thompson had worked out the kinks in his highly scrutinized Veritas merger, and that the consumer-oriented company was poised to benefit from its bold move into enterprise back-up software.   That was premature, judging by the magnitude of the quarterly miss. Symantec blamed much of the problem on its data-center management business (the old Veritas operations). And underperformance from the core Norton anti-virus and security software operations may have hurt more than the company let on, says Morgan Stanley software analyst Peter Kuper.   For now the stock is probably not much better than dead money. Kuper, long a bear on the Veritas deal, figures the stock could edge back up to 19 after last week's slamming -- but the optimism ends there.   Pricing on Norton products is under heavy pressure from Microsoft's (MSFT) entry into the consumer security area, as well as from a rebate program from rival McAfee (MFE). Research outfit NPD Group reported last week that both Symantec and McAfee have been losing market share to Microsoft and smaller competitors.   "The best days [for Norton] are behind us," Kuper contends. "You are going to see that the future is not particularly rosy."   Tougher sledding in the once-booming consumer security-software business wasn't totally unexpected, which is why Veritas-deal fans initially applauded the buyout. New revenues from enterprise clients were meant to provide a more balanced sales mix and greater growth.   But after losing top managers from Veritas, who clashed with Symantec's more button-downed culture, Symantec has yet to prove itself with enterprise customers. Though its Veritas unit is still the leader in data protection and recovery software, with about a 39% share of the market, researcher IDC says the company lost ground to IBM and EMC during the third quarter of last year, the most recently reported.   Some analysts say enterprise customers are resisting the premium prices that Symantec demands for renewable maintenance fees, as dissatisfaction with its customer service begins to fester. CEO Thompson hopes to improve margins by trimming operating costs, which critics argue is affecting the quality of the maintenance service.   The company, which declined to comment pending its complete third-quarter earnings announcement, has cited weaker-than-expected industry spending. But WR Hambrecht analyst Robert Stimson suggests the problems are unique to Symantec.   With the enterprise recovery business stumbling and the Norton consumer franchise getting squeezed from Microsoft, Symantec will now need to deliver several quarters of performance and growth from the Veritas group if it is to win back its whipsawed fans.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Toyota Narrows Choice For US Plant To Two - Report
Story: LITTLE ROCK (AP)--Toyota Motor Corp. (TM) has narrowed its choices for a new automotive manufacturing plant to two - Marion in eastern Arkansas and Chattanooga, Tenn., a newspaper reported Saturday.   The Arkansas Democrat-Gazette cited three unnamed sources the paper said were familiar with the Japanese carmaker's expansion plans. One source said Toyota could choose a location in the next month.   Previous news reports have said the company was considering the Marion and Tennessee sites as well as a location in Crockett County, Tenn., and another site in North Carolina.   Daniel Sieger, spokesman for Toyota in Erlanger, Ky., would only say that Toyota was studying expansion in North America and was researching sites.   Four years ago, the 1,750-acre site near Marion was one of two finalists for Toyota's Tundra pickup plant. Toyota selected San Antonio for the factory, and began production in November. Kay Brockwell, economic development director for Marion, said of the city being a finalist: "I hope that's true." She declined to comment further.   Mitch Chandler, a spokesman for the Arkansas Department of Economic Development, declined to comment.   The Toyota plant would be its eighth in North America. The company was the third-largest U.S. auto manufacturer last year, passing DaimlerChrysler (DCX). Toyota had 15.4% of the U.S. market last year, behind General Motors Corp. (GM) at 24.6% and Ford Motor Co. (F) at 17.5%.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 09:37 ET (14:37 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) Tech Trader: Why It's Too Early To Walk Away From Cisco
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   Shares of Cisco Systems fell 8% last week, to 26.70 by Friday, after analysts at three brokerage firms downgraded the stock from Buy to Neutral. I wrote about the improving prospects for the San Jose, Calif.-based networking giant (ticker: CSCO) back in October when the shares were below 24 ("Getting the World Wired," Oct. 9), so I've got an interest in following up. The stock was actually around 21 when I started chasing Cisco's busy executives for interviews, but youshouldn't have to hear my "inside journalism" excuses.   Tuesday, the stock was downgraded by the analysts at Banc of America Securities and Prudential Equity Group. Wednesday, it was Merrill Lynch. I wondered if those disenamoured analysts had uncovered things amiss in Cisco's business. I wasn't the only one with that question. "Everybody has been calling me to ask if there's any hidden message in the downgrade," said Merrill analyst Tal Liani. "There's not."   Liani believes that Cisco's fundamental business remains well-managed and thriving. The company has video-transmission solutions just as customers like AT&T are rolling out Internet-based television networks. Cisco deployed sales brigades to the world's oil-rich nations and persuaded them to invest in their countries' network infrastructure. When Cisco announces its January quarter results on Feb 6, Liani won't be surprised if it beats his forecast for $8.26 billion in revenues, and earnings of $1.6 billion, or 26 cents a share, including options expense. Those earnings would be 15% higher than the January 2006 quarter's.   With Cisco's operating profit margin at a handsome 29%, Liani wonders if there's much remaining leverage to the company's margins. In recent weeks, every fund manager who calls him about the stock browbeats him for ways that Cisco might ratchet up its margins some more.   I asked the analyst if he wasn't jumping off the Cisco wave too early. After all, YouTube hasn't yet started stocking high-definition videos. Video traffic could grow to levels that force widespread upgrades of Internet gear.   Liani said that he sees Cisco as sort of a growth cyclical company. Right now, it's riding waves with its CRS-1 router for the core of telecom networks and other hot networking products. But waves come in sets, with dull passages in between, and possibly hidden icebergs. He thinks the time to jump is in the middle of the cycle, not the end. His firm is one of Cisco's bankers.   Over at Cisco, I asked if any icebergs had been sighted in the past week. "Cisco is focused on executing against the long-term growth initiatives that we've outlined to our investors for some time now," said spokesperson Heather Dickinson, in a written statement. "Our success to date, as well as our expectations for the future, is based on our belief that the network is the platform for all communications and IT."   That doesn't sound like a pre-announced disappointment to me. I'd guess that Cisco still has a few good quarters ahead of it. Whether you want to race for the exit is your own decision.     The printing-services broker InnerWorkings priced its follow-on stock offering Thursday at $13.50. The firm sold 3 million shares for the business and 5 million shares for insiders -- including the company founders whose histories of underdelivering software have been underreported by InnerWorkings and its bankers at Morgan Stanley.   Last week, I told readers how founder Eric Lefkofsky had the cheek to name his previous venture Starbelly, in apparent tribute to a bamboozling huckster in a Dr. Seuss story, before that venture imploded and took its parent company into bankruptcy.   Numerous ex-employees of InnerWorkings (ticker: INWK) had told me how the company, which claims to develop groundbreaking software to help procure printing services, has misrepresented its "PPM4" software's utility. For instance, InnerWorkings says its software database provides its account managers with instant cost estimates on print jobs, based on historical data. But ex-employees said the estimates were usually not relevant and were scrapped -- claims the company has declined to discuss. Since my first story, I've heard from still others around the printing industry who confirm what I reported.   InnerWorkings spent last weekend meeting with its bankers and lawyers, before issuing a press release Monday that complained of "numerous factual errors" in my column. But the release contained little in the way of rebuttal evidence. One of its more concrete complaints was with my saying that a "big part" of the company's profits came from a related-party transaction in the months before the August 2006 initial offering. In this transaction, a Singapore printing business that's tied to InnerWorkings' chairman licensed the company's software for $1 million. About a half-million dollars' worth of the shares sold last week were the Singapore printer's, so it's already been rewarded for its propitious license deal.   According to InnerWorkings' IPO prospectus, it got $600,000 in payments under the deal during that June 2006 quarter, the last-reported period before the IPO. Typical profit margins on a software or technology license would be more than 80%, which after another 40% cut for the tax man would leave $300,000 net profit from that deal in the quarter, I figure. By my back-of-the-envelope math, that would have been about 17.5% of the quarter's reported net profit of $1.72 million.   In contrast, the company's press release said that the Singapore deal contributed only 7% of its operating profits in the nine months ended September.  Friday, I asked InnerWorkings spokesman Mark Desky to tell me the deal's contribution to the quarter ended June 2006. After noting that the company was still in the "quiet period" of its secondary offering, he said that the Singapore deal brought in less than 9% of June operating profits. That 9% is only half of what I figure. . . but I'm just a writer sitting here in New York; their books, their auditors and now $100 million of some investors' savings are over there in Chicago.   You may have noticed that these quibbles concern rather small amounts of earnings. Let's not lose sight of the forest for the trees: InnerWorkings has produced feeble profits for all its hooey about disrupting the printing industry with software technology. After my story's disclosures led investors to cut InnerWorkings' stock-market capitalization from about $700 million to $600 million, the company is still valued at 100 times trailing earnings. No ink-stained columnist can deter insiders (and their bankers) from printing money at that kind of a price.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) 2007 Barron's Roundtable -- Part -4-
Story: Cohen: My pleasure. My first pick is General Electric [GE], which I mentioned last year. Some of the positive trends we had expected to develop did begin to develop, but not until the autumn, so there is a ways to go. As we all know, this is an extraordinarily diversified company. It is placed in the S&P Industrials category by Standard & Poor's, but it has a lot more going for it, including very significant growth in the medical-technology area, where it is the leader not just in technology but increasingly in sales and service. In addition, because it is a mega-cap stock, it is underowned by lots of portfolio managers. Some proprietary work Goldman Sachs has done on what mutual funds and hedge funds own shows us GE is notably underweighted versus the S&P. That means portfolio managers, to this point, have decided the company is going to underperform. We don't think so.   A number of things set GE apart, including the mix of its business, its international exposure and its very strong balance sheet. It generates lots of cash flow. The company could increase its dividend, and has great capacity to do so. The yield is 2.7%. Unlike some other stocks with yields at about those levels, GE has very good earnings visibility. At a time when the economic cycle is getting a little old, this is a company with annual earnings growth of 9%. We have confidence around that number. Return on equity is about 16%. The current price-earnings multiple based on 2007 results is about 17 times earnings.     Barron's: Because of its diversity, isn't GE awfully exposed to the economy?   Cohen: It is exposed in some ways, but a lot of the products it makes probably are not as cyclically sensitive. Those that are tend to be in the aircraft area, and we feel pretty good about order patterns there. Much of their revenue growth has been coming from medical technology, which is much less exposed.   My second recommendation relates to the consumer. While this is not going to be an extremely robust year for the consumer, we've talked ourselves into believing the consumer is going into a black hole. That is not likely. As a consequence, some consumer-related stocks are now selling at reasonable prices. It is also important to recognize that as the economic cycle ages, consumption patterns change. Early in a cycle, items like housing and autos typically take a fairly large percentage of the total consumer dollar. As the cycle gets older, we see a rotation into discretionary services and spending. My choice here is Royal Caribbean [RCL], the cruise line. It fits neatly into a few themes I've mentioned today. While some consumers aren't feeling terrific, especially with debt problems, the typical Royal Caribbean customer tends to be more upper-middle income and upper income. This is not a budget cruise line. In this higher-income demographic, compensation and household incomes are rising. In addition, Royal Caribbean is benefiting from some company-specific changes.     Barron's: Such as?   Cohen: They have some new ships coming online that will represent 12% or 13% of their capacity, ships for which they'll be able to get premium pricing. The stock did not do particularly well in the first half of 2006, in part due to fuel-related expenses. But costs have eased dramatically and in 2007 are likely to be more benign. Also, there was some competitive pressure coming from other companies that expanded their Caribbean capacity too rapidly. Royal Caribbean is now in the process of shifting some of its ships to Europe.   Today we've talked a lot about the dollar coming under pressure. That is less of an issue with cruises, which have become extremely popular with Americans. You get on the boat. It's easy. You don't have to worry about other transportation and hotels. An American can visit Europe on a Royal Caribbean cruise and pay for it in U.S. dollars. In '07 there could be a substantial increase in the company's revenue, on the order of 13% or 14%. Earnings, which were flattish in '06, could go up about 8%. At 13 times earnings, the stock sells at a discount to its competitors.   Neff: What about viruses and the like that seem to afflict cruise-ship passengers?   Cohen: That creates an opportunity for the maker of those Purell hand wipes! [Pfizer]     Barron's: Now, there's a buy.   Cohen: Another pick in the consumer area is Federated Department Stores [FD]. The company had some problems last year consolidating its acquisition of May Department Stores. It had to shut down some stores, which was part of the plan, but the shares pulled back as a consequence. However, Federated is likely to do much better this year. First, the benefit of the restructuring will begin to show up in the data. And there seems to be a significant difference in the way various retailers are performing. Those that serve lower-income customers are having bigger problems. Federated serves higher-income customers, and is seeing reasonably good comparable-store sales gains. The company most likely will have same-store sales gains on the order of 3% in the year that ends this month, which is not too shabby. Federated also is benefiting from industry consolidation, to which it contributes, as well as shutting down stores. It now has a 30% market share in its category.   Neff: Aren't there some economies of scale?   Cohen: There are economies of scale in terms of buying and negotiating with suppliers and advertising. That was one of the reasons to consolidate some of the stores under the Macy's name.   Black: I own the stock and I like [CEO] Terry Lundgren, but there are a couple of drawbacks. In places like Boston, where Filene's was an institution, and Chicago, where they had Marshall Field's, and Texas, where they had Foley's, a lot of people have been turned off by the Macy's name and the fact that the local brand is gone. I'm not sure how this is going to play out. Federated has strategic issues here.   Cohen: Of course, in Chicago they agreed to continue to provide Franco's, the Marshall Field's candy. Finally, we are seeing margin expansion at Federated. Margins have gone from about 6% to 10%. In fiscal 2007 there was a nasty first quarter, a consequence of all the restructuring going on. Therefore, the shares currently trade for about 18 times fiscal '07 earnings and 13 times the next fiscal year. It is reasonably priced and has good prospects for earnings and margins.   Speaking of health issues on boats, my next two names are in health care. One is MedImmune [MEDI], a specialty pharmaceuticals company. It markets FluMist, which is distributed not only in the U.S., but increasingly overseas. It has been a significant player in the HPV [human papilloma virus] vaccine, which represents one of the truly dramatic changes in public health care. The vaccine has been seen to affect the virus, and therefore eliminate a form of cancer, which is quite extraordinary. The P/E is high, but earnings are about to grow dramatically. Long-term earnings growth is about 18%. Earnings for the year that just ended were about 20 cents a share, and our analyst estimates they'll be about 80 cents this year.     Barron's: Where is the stock?   Cohen: The stock as of Friday [Jan. 5] was 34.32. Again, it's a pretty high P/E, but with the product cycle and likely earnings growth, it's a good place to be. We also like Barr Pharmaceuticals [BRL], one of the largest generic-drug manufacturers. This was not a great category in 2006. People were concerned about the outcome of the midterm elections and a host of other factors. But it seems the secular trends in health care are quite constructive, particularly for the generics. No. 1, cost containment is going to be an important element of everything from here. It is not just a Medicare issue, but an issue for the health plans provided by employers for their current employees and retirees. No. 2, generic drug companies also benefit from demographics: the aging of the population and the fact that people demand good-quality health care, including pharmaceuticals.   The consolidation in the generics business is to the advantage of a company like Barr, which is one of the larger companies and financially robust. The P/E based on 2007 earnings is about 15. The stock on Friday was trading at 52.31. Most generics are not exciting in terms of product development, but they are well situated to benefit from other, secular trends.   Schafer: Abby, the CEO of Barr is one of the brightest in the business. But the business model has changed over the years. We have done a lot of investing in the generic space, but the problem now is that proprietary drug companies are getting into the business, whereas in the past the first to file had six months' exclusivity. Now you have the branded company with an authorized generic in the business, as well. Don't you think that deserves a lower multiple?   Cohen: Absolutely. That's one of the reasons generics in general have been under pressure. This stock was down about 20% last year. A recasting of multiples has occurred in generics, and that's why we like to stay with the larger names. They will have fewer problems keeping up with the big pharmaceutical companies that will try to compete with them.   Schafer: Are Barr's '07 numbers higher than '06?   Cohen: Yes. We estimate Barr will do $3.51 a share this year, versus $3.13 in '06. The consensus for '06 was $3.09, and for this year is $3.39, so we're above consensus.   Black: You ought to point out they might benefit from the Democrat House and Senate. There will be a trend toward generics.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) Unclear LBO Path For Clear Channel
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   Wall Street has watched as private-equity firms generated enormous profits from leveraged buyouts of companies like Hertz, Warner Music and Burger King.   The LBO wave appears to be generating a backlash. The independent directors of Cablevision (ticker: CVC) last week rejected the controlling Dolan family's bid to take it private, calling it inadequate.   Another giant LBO deal is also in trouble. Some big institutional holders of Clear Channel Communicationsare unhappy with the proposed $26 billion leveraged buyout of the radio and billboard giant. They plan to vote against it, believing the $37.60-a-share offer undervalues the company by at least several dollars a share.   This opposition could scuttle the buyout, which is being led by Thomas Lee Partners and Bain Capital Partners, two of the biggest names in private equity. The deal, announced on Nov. 15, also has the backing of the Mays family, which runs Clear Channel (CCU) and owns about 7% of its stock. No date has been set for the shareholder vote; the transaction is slated to close by year end.   Barron's has learned that at least two big institutional holders, including Fidelity Investments, have told management that they will cast negative votes. Fidelity, Clear Channel's largest holder, had an 11% stake at the end of September. Fidelity declined to comment.   Wednesday afternoon, Barron's broke the news of the rising investor resistance to the deal on Barron's Online, our Website.   The opposition by Fidelity and other institutional holders could kill the deal. Clear Channel, the country's largest radio operator, needs the assent of two-thirds of its shareholders to swing it. Holders who don't cast a ballot effectively are voting no. It's estimated that 10% to 15% of shareholders may not vote.   Based on Sept. 30 data, the biggest institutional holders after Fidelity are Morgan Stanley at 8% and Capital Research at 5%. Other sizable holders include NWQ Investments and Highfields Capital Management, a Boston investment firm. Clear Channel, based in San Antonio, wouldn't comment for this article.   If the deal dies, Clear Channel shares could rally because the company's radio business is effectively being valued at an appreciable discount to peers when factoring in the lofty value of Clear Channel's 90% stake in its publicly traded billboard operations, Clear Channel Outdoor Holdings. Clear Channel stock rose 20 cents Thursday to 36.45 after Barron's Online and The Wall Street Journal reported rising investor resistance to the deal. The stock closed Friday at 36.51.   "The LBO price is wholly inadequate," says Jeff Jacobowitz, an analyst at Robotti & Co., a New York investment firm that holds the stock. Jacobowitz, who runs a partnership that owns the stock, says "there's no reason that what management wants to do as a private company can't be done as a public company. That would give the upside to the public shareholders." Among its initiatives, Clear Channel plans to sell a group of small-market radio stations and its TV business.   Bulls argue that Clear Channel shares are attractive because the stock is apt to rise if the buyout bid fails and there's a chance the buyout firms will sweeten their offer. Jacobowitz says Clear Channel is worth at least $42 a share. He cites a research report by Bear Stearns analyst Victor Miller that lays out a scenario in which Clear Channel would remain public and buy back most of its stock, in part by letting shareholders swap their stock for Clear Channel's stake in Clear Channel Outdoor Holdings. (CCO).   Billboards are one of the hottest areas of media, and Clear Channel Outdoor shares have risen to 29 from 21 in the fall. Clear Channel's stake in Clear Channel Outdoor is worth over $9 billion, or half the equity value of Clear Channel Communications. Clear Channel has $8 billion of debt, $2 billion of it associated with Clear Channel Outdoor.   Under Miller's buyback scenario, Clear Channel could generate $5 a share in annual free cash flow in about two years, which Jacobowitz says would produce a stock price of $50 or more.   Miller offered his thoughts in a Jan. 12 note titled "Clear Channel: Take-Under? Radio at 8.2x." Miller wrote that Clear Channel's radio business is being valued at just 8.2 times projected 2007 cash flow, defined as earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, when factoring in the value of the company's stake in Clear Channel Outdoor. In contrast, public radio operators Emmis Communications (EMMS), Cumulus Media (CMLS) and Cox Radio (CXR) are valued at 10 to 11 times projected 2007 cash flow. Clear Channel could trade at $42 a share if its radio business were valued at 10 times projected '07 cash flow.   The institutional holders opposing the deal fear that the buyout firms and the Mays family will make a quick killing on the Clear Channel LBO. The buyout outfits plan to put up about $4 billion in equity and borrow $22 billion to complete the transaction. If Clear Channel's radio business is worth 10 times 2007 cash flow, the value of the buyout firms' equity could be $6 billion or more when the deal closes, giving them an immediate paper profit of $2 billion, a 50% return on their investment.   Clear Channel's three-week auction may have given potential buyers insufficient time to craft their bids. The company announced on Oct. 25 that it was pursuing strategic alternatives after it had been approached by a buyout group, including the Blackstone Group. On Nov. 16, the company announced that the Thomas Lee/Bain group had won an auction with a bid of $37.60, about $5 above the share price on Oct. 24. In contrast, the auction of Univision, the Spanish-language broadcaster, lasted several months in 2006.   The Mays family plans to sell its 35 million shares in the buyout. The bulk of that stock is held by Lowry Mays, the 71-year-old chairman who is the father of Mark Mays, the current chief executive, and Randall Mays, the current president.   Yet Mark and Randall Mays are to retain their jobs when the buyout group takes control and get sizable option packages and a shot at big profits. The two will each get options equal to 2.5% of the equity of the surviving company and be able to roll part of their Clear Channel stock into equity of the private company, according to the preliminary proxy for the deal.   And Clear Channel's investment banker, Goldman Sachs (GS), stands to make a fee of $40 million for advising the company. The bulk of that fee is payable only on consummation of the deal.   Clear Channel shares have languished in recent years as ad dollars shifted out of radio to the Internet and as the company cut commercial time to reduce clutter.   However, the radio market seems to be turning up, and the billboard business is hotter than ever, partly because of the potential for digital signs. Billboard operators like Lamar Advertising (LAMR) have some of the highest valuations in the media world -- 15 to 16 times projected 2007 cash flow.   "We are one of the best-performing companies in the media industry," CEO Mark Mays said in the press release announcing Clear Channel's third-quarter earnings. Radio operating income rose 8% to $185 million in the period on a 5% rise in revenues.   Institutional holders are now sending a message to Wall Street that investors are tired of seeing LBO outfits make a killing at their expense. For Clear Channel, the buyout firms may have to offer at least $42 a share to get this deal done.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) When A Hot Stock Breaks A Sweat
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Christopher C. Williams   Forget Michael Jordan. Kevin Plank, chairman of Under Armour, wants to be like Phil Knight, the legendary founder of Nike.   Like Knight -- an ex-athlete who built a $15 billion global empire by turning high-priced kicks into must-have items for weekend warriors and elite athletes alike -- Plank, a college footballer, is carving out a niche in the $14 billion active-sports-apparel market by selling pricey shirts and shorts through in-your-face advertising, keen knowledge of the sports market and smart brand management.   Sales for Plank's Baltimore-based Under Armour (ticker: UA) are believed to have hit $421 million in 2006, up from just $5 million in 2000, as teens and college athletes snapped up Under Armour's core product -- tight-fitting synthetic shirts that wick away sweat from the body.   The start-up's swift success has fans touting Under Armour as the next Nike. The 34-year-old Plank generally downplays such talk, but he boldly predicts that his company will grow to $1 billion and eventually will become "the world's No. 1 performance brand." Investors seem to believe it, bidding up Under Armour more than 100% since its November 2005 debut, to a recent 51. (The stock, which came public on Nasdaq, moved to the NYSE in December.)   But based on almost every valuation metric, investors are paying too much for Plank's big-league aspirations.   Under Armour's stock is selling for more than 80 times its earnings of the past 12 months, and 53 times the 96 cents a share analysts are projecting for this year. That price-earnings ratio is a towering 2.76 times the rate of earnings growth. In contrast, Nike, with a market value 14 times Under Armour's and the most respected brand in sports, is selling for 17 times this year's earnings and at just 1.16 times earnings growth.   Moisture management simply shouldn't be so pricey. There's a good case that the stock ought to be no higher than the low 40s, about 12% below current levels. And if the still-young company stumbles in managing its growth, the shares conceivably could fall much further. The fact is, growing to $1 billion is still anything but a slam dunk.   Already, big competitors are moving in. While Under Armour controls about 75% of the $500 million market for tight sweat-busting gear, Nike (NIKE) and Adidas-Salomon (ADS.Germany), which don't much like getting sand kicked in their faces, have introduced their own lines and are moving to boost their market shares.   Under Armour, for its part, has been diversifying into athletic footwear, including football cleats. But that's a famously crowded arena, one likely to crimp the company's margins.   Concludes Brady Lemos, an analyst at Morningstar: "We believe the market's rich valuation of Under Armour is based on lofty revenue and profit-growth projections that will be difficult to sustain as the business matures."   Yes, Under Armour continues to grow faster than the more mature Nike. On Feb. 1, Under Armour is likely to report that earnings per share for '06 more than doubled to 80 cents, according to analysts, while sales jumped 50%. The company also is likely to meet or beat earnings expectations of 25 cents a share for the fourth quarter. And for the next five years, earnings and sales could climb at a spiffy 25% to 30% annual rate.   Fans reckon that Under Armour, with a market value of $2.4 billion, is just beginning to tap its growth opportunities, particularly with women and overseas markets. "Don't be hung up on the price," advises Under Armour shareholder Tom Forte of Geneva Investment Management of Chicago, who bought the shares last January in the low 30s. "Think about what the company can be. You have to believe in the company -- and I do."   Leaps of faith like that could help keep the stock up for a while. And heavy short-selling -- some 25% of the publicly available shares have been shorted -- could accelerate any further rises in the share price, with shorts forced to buy back shares to cover their positions.   Indeed, legions of skeptics have been burned betting against apparently pricey, hypergrowth stocks, a fact Barron's noted a year ago in casting a skeptical eye on Under Armour's lofty valuation (The Trader, Jan. 23, 2006). Under Armour has advanced 33% since then.   But the nosebleed valuation leaves Plank & Co. little room for error. The stock slipped after the company beat third-quarter earnings expectations by several pennies, suggesting that pleasing investors' appetite might be growing increasingly difficult. "At 51, you need meaningful upside to earnings guidance to warrant that type of price," says analyst Eric Tracy of BB&T Capital Markets.   Like many of the 11 sell-side analysts who follow Under Armour, Tracy lauds the company's business model and bright growth prospects. But he has a Hold rating on the stock, joining seven other analysts who are wary of the valuation. Tracy notes, for example, that Under Armour trades at a significant premium to the average price-earnings ratio of a select group of active-wear companies, including VF (VFC) and Oakley (OO).   Hedge-fund manager Peter Siris of Guerrilla Capital in New York is similarly conflicted. "There are too many momentum players for me to be short and too high a valuation for me to be long," he tells Barron's.   The sell-side analysts who follow Under Armour post an average price target of 44, valuing the shares at a more reasonable 46 times '07 earnings. But even that target also still assumes robust 25%-plus annual earnings growth.   That happens to be the precise value that Goldman Sachs, an underwriter for Under Armour's initial public offering, has placed on the stock. Goldman analyst Margaret Mager initiated coverage of Under Armour with essentially a Neutral rating last February, and repeated it in October, with the stock at 46.35. In a report at the time, Mager reminded investors that the apparel business grows in a pattern of steps, with periods of accelerated growth followed by consolidation of gains. "Trends remain strong," said the analyst, "but are already reflected in the share price, leaving downside risks if growth should slow."   Executives at Under Armour declined to comment for this article, citing a need to be quiet until earnings are released.   But it's clear that slowing down is anathema to Plank, a Baltimore native who worked his way from a walk-on with the University of Maryland football squad to a team captain. He felt weighed down by the sweaty cotton T-shirts he wore while playing sports, and felt certain other athletes felt the same. In 1995, he raised $20,000, hired a tailor to make T-shirts from spandex material and peddled them to schools along the East Coast, much as Knight started Nike by selling sneakers from the trunk of his car.   Made of a mixture of polyester or nylon and elastane, Under Armour's long-sleeved shirt, for example, hugs the body like a second skin and, unlike cotton, pulls moisture away from the torso and outside the shirt. This system, Under Armour says, regulates body temperature in all weather, making you more comfortable and able to perform better. The crew-neck long-sleeve comes at a hefty $48, compared with, say, $10 for a typical cotton shirt.   Today, Under Armour sells some 300 exercise-apparel styles and accessories infused with its moisture-management technology, including loose apparel, sports bras and backpacks, through more than 9,000 outlets. The company also targets golf and hunting.   Under Armour says it expects its international business to more than triple this year, though it will still be less than 5% of sales. The company is ramping up sales to women and children, and last summer it introduced football cleats -- grabbing, according to Plank, 22% of that business. The company is now said to be eyeing basketball kicks, where Nike and Adidas rule.   So far, Plank has expanded the brand without a major hitch -- but it's still early in the game, and it's uncertain whether management can skillfully expand the business to take advantage of growth opportunities.   Analysts expect gross margins to inch up to about 50% this year, from 48.3% in '05, but the improvement could be curtailed as Under Armour expands into tough markets like footwear. Margins could come under pressure unless Under Armour boosts sales volume, changes its sales mix or takes lower-cost sourcing initiatives, says BB&T's Tracy.   Expanding overseas has its pitfalls. Mager of Goldman notes three of them: The Under Armour brand isn't well-known outside the U.S.; its historical association with American football might not translate well; and it doesn't benefit from the first-mover advantage that it has enjoyed in the U.S.   That advantage, too, could erode as more companies push into the business. The main rivals are Berkshire Hathaway's Russell unit, with lower-priced products; Adidas, with its ClimateCool brand; and, mainly, Nike, whose Nike Pro business is growing in the high double-digits, analysts say.   Under Armour doesn't have a patent on the fabric or its sweat-busting process, so it has to rely mainly on its brand name to ward off rivals. While Under Armour's interlocking U and A logo might rule the anti-sweat market now, the swoosh is the undisputed king of sporting goods. And analysts say Nike is devoting more than $30 million of marketing muscle to its product line -- dwarfing Under Armour's total ad budget.   There's long been speculation that Nike and Adidas each would like to buy Under Armour. Those companies wouldn't comment. Plank has said he's turned down acquisition overtures in the past, and analysts figure that the supercompetitive executive, who holds 80% voting control through ownership of the super-voting Class B shares, wants to play out the game as an independent.   Any acquirer, meanwhile, is sure to think long and hard before paying 50-plus times earnings. Savvy investors might want to do the same.   ---   Superman's Basketball Game     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: WSJ(1/20) Home Depot Directors To Visit Activist Investor
Story: (From THE WALL STREET JOURNAL)     By Ann Zimmerman and Joann S. Lublin   Several Home Depot Inc. board members are expected by midweek to visit with activist investor Ralph V. Whitworth, who has threatened to launch a proxy fight for a board seat if the company doesn't reassess its business strategy.   Mr. Whitworth, a principal of San Diego-based investment fund Relational Investors LLC, was a leading critic of former Chief Executive Robert Nardelli's performance. And the activist investor maintains that some big changes are needed to boost the company's stagnant stock price now that Mr. Nardelli is gone.   Even though Home Depot is extending the olive branch to Mr. Whitworth, future spats are likely. Mr. Whitworth, 51 years old, has said he wants Home Depot to spin off its lower-margin supply business and focus on its stores, while newly appointed CEO Frank Blake remains committed to continuing Mr. Nardelli's diversification strategy that Mr. Blake himself helped craft and implement.   Home Depot has spent $7 billion acquiring wholesale-supply businesses in the last several years. "They should sell them and get what they can for them, because they make no sense," Mr. Whitworth told The Wall Street Journal in December, after his efforts to raise a fuss at Home Depot became public. Mr. Whitworth, whose fund owns a 1.3% stake in the retailer, had alerted Home Depot that the fund planned to introduce a resolution at Home Depot's May shareholder meeting asking the board to establish a committee of independent board members to review the company's strategic direction, management performance and to explore possible alternatives, including a sale of the company.   Citing a recent visit to a San Diego Home Depot, where he couldn't find a salesperson to help him, Mr. Whitworth said in December that the company's flagging customer service was one reason competitor Lowe's Corp. was "taking them to the cleaners" and that the company shouldn't be pursuing acquisitions until it adequately invests in its stores.   Home Depot has been courting Mr. Whitworth ever since Mr. Nardelli abruptly resigned Jan. 2, after declining to curb his pay package significantly. The board members are meeting with Mr. Whitworth to signal that the board is anxious to hear Mr. Whitworth's ideas for improving the company, according to someone close to the board.   Whether the visit will succeed in quieting down Mr. Whitworth, who has a long track record of shaking up underperforming companies, is unclear. "Nardelli was a peace offering by the board, but they are not going to have peace" with Mr. Whitworth, predicts Randy Lampert, one of the two heads of the recently formed shareholder-activist group at investment bank Morgan Joseph & Co. The group advises firms that have been targeted by activist shareholders. Home Depot isn't a client.   What's more, Mr. Whitworth has already made up his mind to seek at least one seat on the Home Depot board regardless of what he hears from board members, according to a person familiar with the situation.   The Whitworth visit is the latest chapter in a charm offensive that began after the 57-year-old Mr. Blake suddenly was placed in command of the second-biggest retailer in the U.S. Mr. Blake has already talked to Wall Street analysts and impressed them with his down-to-earth manner, a big change from the imperious Mr. Nardelli.   Mr. Blake also stressed to analysts his interest in improving the store experience, hiring executives with the retail experience he lacks and restoring the company's entrepreneurial and fun culture.   While Mr. Blake is promising a new day at Home Depot, the board in numerous ways has strongly telegraphed that it is still committed to its previous strategic path. For starters, it selected as CEO Mr. Blake, who has no previous retail experience and was the chief architect of the wholesale-building-supply division. Mr. Blake recently told investors he is adamant about pursuing growth in that segment.   Meanwhile, on the same day it announced Mr. Nardelli's resignation, Home Depot said it was waiving mandatory retirement for a year for three directors who otherwise would have to step down because they are past 72 years old. The company said in a statement that it wanted the directors to provide continuity during this time of change, but others see it as a move to block Mr. Whitworth's attempt to run for any seats.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:30 ET (05:30 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Japan Listed Firms Steadily Adopt 401(k) Pension Plans
Story: TOKYO (Nikkei)--An increasing number of listed companies in Japan are introducing defined-contribution pension plans for their employees, with Canon Inc. (7751.TO) and Q.P. Corp. (2809.TO) launching Japanese versions of 401(k) schemes earlier this month and Yamato Holdings Co. (9064.TO) planning to do so soon, The Nikkei reported in its Sunday edition.   The outstanding balance of assets managed under such plans reached an estimated Y3 trillion at the end of last year, with 2.15 million workers participating in them as of the end of November.   About 30,000 Canon employees, including those of group firms, have joined the company's 401(k)-type plan.  Japan's top manufacturer of personal computer printers intends to divert to the scheme 20%-30% of the contributions channeled into its conventional defined-benefit pension program.   Meanwhile, Q.P., the country's largest mayonnaise producer, offers the plan as well as a system to pay retirement allowances in advance.  The new program is expected to attract 1,800 participants.   Yamato's plan, which is due to be launched in late January, will cover about 77,000 employees at the leading home parcel delivery company and group firms.  The company will not dissolve the existing defined-benefit program, but instead allow workers to choose the one they want to participate in.   Rival Nippon Express Co. (9062.TO) is also considering adopting a 401(k)-type pension system.   Japanese companies began adopting defined-contribution pension plans in autumn 2001, with 2,161 companies and corporate groups making them available to their employees by the end of December last year.   The balance of assets under management by dedicated investment trusts, one of the investment vehicles for 401(k) pension plans, exceeded Y1 trillion for the first time at the end of last year according to a survey by Quick Corp. and QBR Corp.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 10:30 ET (15:30 GMT)

Headline: TCG Exec: No Plans To Offer Public Stake In Morgan Stanley JV
Story: RIYADH (Zawya Dow Jones)--Saudi Arabia's The Capital Group asserts that it has no plans to offer a stake in its newly announced joint venture with Morgan Stanley in the Saudi market in its initial public offering to local investors, Fahad Al Mubarak, TCG Chairman and Managing Director, told Dow Jones Saturday.   "We haven't determined the size or the shareholders' ownership in the new company. We will come to define all these details by the end of first quarter of 2007. TCG is entirely owned by its employees. We have no plans to offer a stake in the new company to the public," Al Mubarak said.   Morgan Stanley announced Jan. 17 its intention to enter into a joint venture agreement with The Capital Group. The joint venture will operate under the name of Morgan Stanley Saudi Arabia. However, a Saudi Capital Market Authority official said Saturday that the joint venture will need the regulator's approval.   "We haven't received any official request from the company yet. Any change in the structure of ownership in any licensed firm requires the approval of the CMA," Abdullah Al Qahtani, General Manager for licensing in CMA told Dow Jones.   Al Qahtani pointed out that they look at mergers case by case, and the regulator focus will bring the best qualified firms into the market.   Al Mubarak said that the benefit will mutual for both sides as the partnership with the renowned investment bank, which has international reach, will straighten TCG's relations with the international clients, while the local presence will provide rich offerings to Morgan Stanley in the Saudi market.   The Capital Group was founded by Dr. Fahad Al Mubarak in 2001, and holds licenses from the Capital Markets Authority in Saudi Arabia to offer investment advisory, investment banking, asset management and trading services. The new company will provide brokerage services which are expected to grow rapidly.   The Morgan Stanley statement said that Al Mubarak will remain as Chairman and Managing Director of the joint venture, which will initially employ 25 professionals.     -By Anees Al Qudaihi, Dow Jones Newswires; +966 1 2914872; anees.alqudaihi@dowjones.com      Copyright (c) 2007 ABQ Zawya Ltd.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 09:29 ET (14:29 GMT)

Headline: Barron's(1/22) When A Hot Stock Breaks A Sweat -2-
Story: If clothes make the man, does Under Armour's skin-tight, sweat-busting T-shirt make a better basketball player? That's certainly the message the Baltimore company has tried to put out.   I had my doubts, but as a middle-aged weekend warrior who sweats buckets at the slightest physical exertion, I figured it was worth a try. So I donned Under Armour's black crew-neck long-sleeved shirt and headed off to my weekly game of hoops.   It works -- at least the sweat-busing part. I ended two hours of spirited play almost as dry as I began, with the form-fitting shirt wicking sweat away from my body.   Alas, I didn't detect any uptick in my game. Shots clanked off the rim with their usual frequency. I also felt more than a tad self-conscious, standing around clad like a super hero. When no one was watching, I pulled in my stomach, flexed my biceps and took a long, appraising look at my torso.   Memo to self: Do more pushups -- or try the looser-fit T.   -- C.C.W.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) The Trader: Tech Stocks Suffer As Earnings Season Opens
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Vito J. Racanelli   Stocks put in a mixed showing in a holiday-shortened week as the Nasdaq fell but the other major indexes finished mostly unchanged. Shares received another boost from lower energy prices and favorable economic news, but earnings from some big tech names failed to impress, weighing the sector down.   The Dow Jones Industrial Average, which closed at 12,565.53, and the Standard & Poor's 500, which finished at 1430.50, were nearly flat versus their levels the previousFriday. The tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite fell 2%, to 2451.31.   For data junkies, there were ample macroeconomic reports to parse, like inflation and industrial production, among others. The upshot is a U.S. that is expanding at a nicely measured pace, but with prices needing to be watched. The University of Michigan said Friday that its January consumer-sentiment reading had jumped to 98, the highest level in three years, from 91.7 last month and above forecasts of 92. "The economic data continue to affirm that the economy is remarkably resilient," says Ed Yardeni, president of Yardeni Research.   Meanwhile, the earnings-reporting season began in earnest. Tech stocks were smacked on profits and outlooks from the likes of Apple (ticker: AAPL), IBM (IBM) and Intel (INTC) that were unimpressive or partly disappointing.   With 70 of the S&P 500's members reporting as of last Thursday, the ratio of firms beating fourth-quarter analysts' earnings estimates to those missing them was a respectable 2.2 to 1, says Dirk van Dijk, director of research at Zacks Investment Research. "That's not nearly as good as has been the case at this point in previous earnings seasons, but it's early yet," he adds. Tech watchers, however, should note that consensus-estimate revisions for 2007 are "noticeably weak," he notes, with tech analysts making three reductions for each upward revision.   Next week promises a large slug of earnings reports.     Crude rose Friday to finish at $52 a barrel. But that was still down $1 on the week, on sharply rising U.S. inventories. Although the stock market still expects an interest-rate cut this year, the plunge in energy prices, if sustained, could effectively act as a partial rate cut, perhaps putting off a Fed that shows no signs of easing yet.   At oil's peak last summer, global energy users would have paid the equivalent of $2 trillion, annualized, to producers, says Yardeni. At current prices, again annualized, their oil bills would be down by at least $500 billion. That's roughly equivalent to 4% of U.S. annual GDP, or more than 100% of Switzerland's.   The week's food for thought: It took just 15 days for the Dems in power to raise taxes. The House passed an energy bill, HR6, which creates the first net tax increase since 1993, according to Daniel Clifton, executive director of the American Shareholders Association, a nonprofit lobbyist for investor interests.     Tesoro Petroleum (TSO) is sitting on a treasure of cash, probably more than it needs to run the business efficiently. At the end of 2006, the San Antonio-based refiner, with a market-capitalization of $4.8 billion and $1 billion in debt, will likely end up with about $800 million in cash. That stash could reach $1 billion this year.   But what's a refiner to do, when, because of past missteps, investors will potentially react negatively to a big acquisition or to a major internal investment?   Friedman Billings Ramsey analyst Jacques Rousseau argues that the best use of the cash is a big buyback of its own shares, say $1 billion worth, to take out some 20% of the 67 million outstanding shares at the current 70.67 per share. He figures Tesoro could use a mix of about $600 million in cash plus additional debt to accomplish the share repurchase.   Tesoro hasn't reduced the share count much in recent years, he says, so such a buyback would make a "material" impact on earnings per share, increasing estimated profits about 18% this year by lowering shares outstanding. A similar move by refiner Ultramar Diamond Shamrock in 2001 led to a 26% rise in the stock price over the next 12 weeks, he points out. With oil and refined-product prices falling, refiners will likely see share volatility in 2007, and there will be chances to buy back the stock at prices lower than it is now.   Tesoro declined to comment on the report, but says it uses excess cash to create shareholder value by raising dividends, repurchasing shares and making capital investments.     Returns from value stocks, which have low price-earnings ratios and growth rates, have crushed growth stocks over the past decade. But in the six months since the market's lows last summer, growth stocks show inchoate signs of waking from a long torpor.   Although the current differential is small -- the Russell 1000 growth index is up 17% since mid-July, compared with 15% for the Russell 1000 value index -- it is intriguing, and potentially conducive to momentum-investment strategies. Rather than employing fundamental analysis, momentum investors look for stocks that show strong relative price outperformance, with the idea that stocks that go up tend to continue going up near-term.   "We are in a unique environment in which certain stocks that perform better than the averages continue to outperform peers," says David Kovacs, a portfolio manager at Turner Investment Partners. With growth trying to make a comeback, "this is one of those times when momentum strategies work."   In particular, there appears to be a move in asset-allocation strategies to growth from value, as well as a subtle shift to larger companies, he notes. Most large institutional investors can't make that shift overnight. Hence, once big mutual funds begin to do so, the effects on stock prices tend to persist, Kovacs adds.   The first phase of the accumulation process started back in July, coming out of the lows, he says, and has accelerated this month, after the market pause from mid-December to early January.   Kovacs has screened for companies with strong fundamental business trends and above-average short-term relative stock strength in the Jan. 5 to 17 period, in the belief that they will continue to outdo the market for the next two to four months as big fund managers pile in. (A portion of the screen is presented on the previous page.)   If institutions keep shifting to growth, then the next two to four months are likely to show excess returns for these stocks, he predicts.     Investors looking for an even shorter investment time frame might take a look at after-hours trading and what light it can shed on which way a stock will go the next day.   After-hours trading, which came of age during the stock-market bubble of 2000, remains the stepchild of traditional day-session trading. Many pros still view the various evening markets -- accessed through Instinet, among others -- as relatively illiquid and manned by nonprofessionals and naive stock jockeys, hence not indicative of the trading the next day.   That view may miss the mark.   Stocks develop distinct and consistent trading patterns in after-hours dealings, and it is a deeper market than many believe, contends Keith Lanigan, managing editor of a subscription Website aimed at such traders, www.midnighttrader.com, which began in 2000. "It's like a window on next day's trading," he says.   There are stocks in which this phenomenon is particularly clear, adds Lanigan, who's been studying a wide range of shares looking for patterns. Some shares that have risen in the evening session after the official 4 p.m. close increase even further in the next day's traditional session. And some stocks that fall in the evening continue that decline the following day.   One stock showing predictability is Apple, he says. For example, in after-hours trading last Wednesday, following Apple's fiscal first-quarter earnings report earlier that day, Apple fell about 1.1%, to 94, by the time the evening session thinned out. In Thursday's regular session, Apple dropped 6%, to 89. Also Wednesday, Lam Research (LRCX), which fell 7% to 50 in the evening session after it released fiscal second-quarter results, declined 15% Thursday to 46.22. In both cases, shorting the shares in evening trading would have paid off the following day.   Lanigan says other candidates that report earnings this coming week and have shown after-hours tradeable patterns in the past are: Texas Instruments (TXN), on Monday; Avaya (AV), Citrix (CTXS), Yahoo! (YHOO) and QLogic (QLGC), Tuesday; Novellus Systems (NVLS) and Netflix (NFLX), Wednesday; and Synaptics (SYNA), Thursday.   What's behind this? Probably, the next day's trading sees analysts' ratings changes, as well as big players piling on or exiting, amplifying the move of the previous evening session. For those wanting to test Lanigan's predictions, free sights like Yahoo! Headline: =WSJ: Acting Bristol-Myers CEO Looks Beyond Nightmare Year
Story: By Sarah Rubenstein     Of THE WALL STREET JOURNAL     NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--James Cornelius, the interim chief executive of Bristol-Myers Squibb Co. (BMY), will try to bring an end this week to a year-long nightmare involving the company's best-selling drug - a series of missteps that led to his predecessor's ouster.   Monday, Bristol-Myers heads to court in hopes of re-establishing its exclusive U.S. rights to the blood-thinner Plavix. Thursday, the company will report earnings that will be severely depressed partly because of a brief period last year in which it lost those rights.   (This story and related background material will be available on The Wall Street Journal Web site, WSJ.com.)   Many observers believe that Bristol-Myers, with a crop of new drugs at a time when the industry's pipeline is running dry, makes an attractive takeover candidate and that bids will emerge once the Plavix uncertainty has passed. Mr. Cornelius, who took the job in September, maintains that Bristol-Myers can remain independent.   But, in an interview, Mr. Cornelius acknowledged that his optimism about the company's future is predicated on keeping the Plavix patent. A loss in the trial over the drug - a nearly $4 billion seller for Bristol-Myers in 2005 - would mean "a complete rethink of what we're trying to do," he said. He spoke at the company's offices in Lawrenceville, N.J.   Bristol-Myers said in December it expects to announce 2006 profits of 72 cents to 77 cents a share, compared with $1.52 a share in 2005. Sales of the company's second-biggest seller, cholesterol-lowering drug Pravachol, faced generic competition for the first time in the United States and some European markets last year, weighing on the company's profits.   Then there was the unexpected blow last August, when Apotex Inc., following failed negotiations with Bristol-Myers to delay generic Plavix until 2011, briefly flooded a generic version of the drug on the market.   The prevailing view is that Bristol-Myers and Sanofi-Aventis SA (12057.FR) of France, which originally discovered Plavix and co-markets the drug with Bristol-Myers, are likely to win the patent trial, in U.S. District Court in New York.   That view is based in part on the conclusion of Judge Sidney Stein, who, in granting a preliminary injunction halting Apotex's sales of the generic last year, wrote that Bristol-Myers and Sanofi were likely to succeed. Plavix's patent is set to expire in 2011.   In the third quarter, the generic ate into sales of the branded drug by $525 million to $600 million. Once supplies of the generic are depleted, Bristol-Myers says it expects its own sales of Plavix to return to normal.   That done, Bristol-Myers - having put a number of challenges largely behind it - should transition into a growth period, analysts say. After Pravachol, the company won't face another patent expiration on a major drug until at least 2011.   Late last year, the company reached a preliminary agreement with the Justice Department and the U.S. Attorney in Massachusetts to settle investigations into its drug- pricing, sales and marketing practices. In the middle of this year comes the expiration of a deferred-prosecution agreement with the U.S. attorney in New Jersey following an accounting scandal, under which Bristol-Myers pledged to conduct itself lawfully for two years to avoid criminal indictments. And Bristol-Myers still faces ongoing investigations related to its handling of Plavix.   Meanwhile, the company has launched new drugs and improved its pipeline.   "Earnings have been poor for a number of years, but now they're depressed and they're poised to accelerate," said  Barbara Ryan, a pharmaceutical analyst at Deutsche Bank. Bristol-Myers is an investment-banking client of Deutsche Bank.   It's not clear when Bristol-Myers will replace Mr. Cornelius with a permanent successor. While reiterating that he's not a candidate for the job, Mr. Cornelius said he would stay in the interim post as long as he's needed.   He pointed out that the company's board has said it's weighing internal and external candidates equally, but he added that the board would prefer somebody with CEO experience.   Mr. Cornelius says he backs the strategy mapped out by his predecessor, Peter Dolan, which is to focus heavily on diseases treated by specialist physicians, such as cancer and HIV, while maintaining a smaller sales force for primary-care medications.   Mr. Cornelius is also eyeing costs. The company has said it would cut $500 million in expenses in 2007 and $100 million in 2008. Mr. Cornelius said there is room for "probably another $1 billion" in savings.   Then Bristol-Myers will have to deliver on some of the drugs now in its pipeline. After years of lackluster performance by its research-and-development organization, Bristol-Myers launched eight new products in the U.S. from 2003 to 2006, half of them discovered in-house.   The company hopes eventually to shift its number of in-house discoveries to about two-thirds of its drugs, said Andrew Bonfield, the chief financial officer. It also says it's looking to enter more partnerships with other drug companies - potentially including large rivals - as a way to reduce the costs and risks of drug development.   This month, Bristol-Myers and drug giant AstraZeneca PLC (AZN.LN), announced a partnership to develop and market two experimental drugs for Type 2 diabetes discovered by Bristol-Myers.   -By Sarah Rubenstein of The Wall Street Journal; 212-416-4406, sarah.rubenstein@wsj.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 14:44 ET (19:44 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(1/22) 2007 Barron's Roundtable -- Part 2: Mixing It Up
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Lauren R. Rublin   At the annual Barron's Roundtable, we spend the morning surveying the forest. After lunch, we examine the trees. How do you turn big-picture views about the economy, interest rates and equity markets into winning stocks, bonds and funds? Therein lies the essence of successful investing.   Fortunately, few folks on the planet have been more successful at translating macro themes into money than the 12 market mavens who graced our Jan. 8 event, including the five -- Bill Gross, Archie MacAllaster, Abby Cohen, Felix Zulauf and John Neff -- whose investment picks form the basis of this week's Roundtable installment.   In last week's Barron's, Bill Gross cast Pimco, his giant West Coast bond-investment firm, as a mere bit player in the fixed-income markets, sandwiched between the world's central banks on the one hand and giant asset allocators like the OPEC nations on the other. Even so, Bill remains our go-to guy for bonds, as he demonstrates again in the current issue by picking a pair of fixed-income funds from Pimco and its cross-country rival, BlackRock. His expertise extends to currencies, as well, including the laboring dollar. That's why he's also recommending the iShares MSCI EAFE fund -- for rest-of-the-world exposure.   For Archie MacAllaster, the animating theme is valuation, or the opportunity to buy fast-growing and financially healthy companies for much less than they're worth. The chairman of New York's MacAllaster, Pitfield MacKay, Archie made his name in financial services, and to that arena he returns with kind words for Hartford Financial, Capital One and Arch Capital. "Wish I were that Arch," he quips.   The great bull market has come and gone, but Abby Cohen, Goldman Sachs' unflappable U.S. investment strategist, remains, explaining the post-bubble world as expertly as she discoursed on its manic predecessor. Abby's not a stockpicker but a stock peruser, scanning Goldman's Buy list for companies that amplify her ideas. The U.S. consumer has yet to fall down on the job, which should benefit cruise-line operator Royal Caribbean and Federated Department Stores. The government's efforts to contain health-care costs should bolster generic-drug makers such as Barr Pharmaceuticals. You get the picture. You'll also get the good word on General Electric, currently one of her favorites.   Never mind that Felix Zulauf, head of Switzerland's Zulauf Asset Management, is a wise student of markets and manias. He's also tops in currencies, commodities and whole countries, as his table-pounding pitch for Singapore suggests. Felix also likes back-from-the-dead European telecoms and Brazilian oil giant Petrobras, though most of his recommendations come with an asterisk: Please, please don't buy them until prices correct. Felix, you see, thinks world markets will sell off sharply in coming months, setting the stage for the bull's next big run.   John Neff, like Archie a consummate value investor, rounds out this week's stock- picking session. Both, as it turns out, are recommending Lyondell Chemical, which affords an opportunity to study how two savvy investors approach the same company. John retired some years back from the helm of the Vanguard Windsor Fund, but his eye is on the ball more than ever these days -- and on land-driller Nabors and his old friend Citigroup.   Please read on for the picks and preferences of all five pros, as well as the well-timed queries and amusing asides of their colleagues 'round the table.     Barron's: Give us a few ideas, Bill   Gross: My selections are predicated to a considerable extent upon the premise that the Federal Reserve will be lowering interest rates by midyear, and that interest rates on the longer end of the Treasury yield curve will be a function of asset allocations by relatively price-insensitive foreign central banks and reserve accumulators. Risk markets in general are somewhat at risk because of the potential for oil-producers' reserves to decline and for those monies to be withheld from the markets, to which they clearly were allocated in 2006. I am not necessarily suggesting that there will be a precipitous decline in financial assets, but that spreads are at risk of widening in the credit markets, and prices perhaps could be stagnant on the equity side.   Also -- and this view is endorsed by many people around this table -- the dollar ultimately is, if not a doomed currency, a weak currency relative to the rest of the world. The U.S. requires a depreciating currency to pay its bills to the rest of the world. We will get a weak dollar despite [Treasury Secretary Hank] Paulson's and prior Treasury secretaries' admonitions that they favor a strong-dollar policy. Treasury secretaries and domestic policy will have to favor weak-dollar movements in the future. So a weak dollar and risk markets somewhat at risk in 2007 form the basis for my selections today, many of which are bond-oriented.     Barron's: OK, let's have 'em.   Gross: My first pick, iShares MSCI EAFE, a Barclays exchange-traded fund [ticker: EFA], relates to my weak-dollar-policy thesis but at the same time allows investors to participate in the equity markets. It's one I recommended last year, and it did very well. It encompasses all markets other than the U.S., and is denominated in non-dollar currencies. This is an index fund of a thousand stocks. Fees are relatively low, which is important. All investors should continue to focus on how much they pay for asset management. This one has an overall expense ratio of 35 basis points [a basis point is one one-hundredth of a percentage point], so that's pretty cheap. Many investors, even yours truly, may wonder how to buy foreign currencies in a relatively inexpensive way. This is one way to do it, plus you capture long-term equity exposure. The fund has a 20% Japan orientation and a 20% U.K. exposure. The balance is in euroland, Asia and other positions.   Gabelli: Isn't this a diluted way to participate in these markets? The Japanese sell to the U.S., and their earnings get depressed if the dollar gets weaker.   Gross: I suspect the dollar will depreciate at a 5%-plus annual rate. To the extent that you get a 5% kicker in terms of dollar weakness, that more than makes up for the dilution. This is a great diversifier. U.S. investors are too focused domestically. They think everything revolves around the U.S. economy. In fact, global corporations, many of which are U.S.-based, have lots of foreign earnings. By buying them, U.S. investors participate globally. But they also need to go outside the U.S., and this ETF does that, giving them non-dollar exposure. One of the ways people will be able to retire going forward is to extract earnings and wealth from the rest of the world, which is growing faster than the U.S., certainly in currency-denominated terms. This is a cheap way to participate.   Next, I'm going to recommend a bond market -- the Japanese bond market -- which might raise some questions. On the surface, it provides a yield of only 1.50%. Investors everywhere, even me before I snap myself to with smelling salts, wonder how you can turn a 1.5% yield into something that supposedly is attractive to investors. The way to do that is to buy a JGB [Japanese government bond] future [JBH7] via the commodities exchange. That's the March contract for this JGB 10-year bond, which yields about 1.5%. As a buyer, you basically take that 1.50% and apply it to the money-market rate of the country you are in. With money-market rates in Japan at 25 basis points, this yields only 1.5% to 1.75%. But if you're in euroland, you attach the 1.5% yield to 3.5% or 3.75% local money-market rates, and suddenly you have a 5.2% bond guaranteed by the Japanese government.     Barron's: And in the U.S.?   Gross: With the federal-funds rate at 5.25%, you tack on the 1.5% JGB yield and you've got 6.75%. That is almost as competitive, and in some cases more competitive than junk bonds. It's hard to explain how you could buy a bond at 1.50% and turn it into a 6.75% yield, but that's simply the way it works. [Buying a Japanese bond-futures contract and investing in a U.S.-dollar money market at 5.25% is similar to buying a Japanese bond and hedging the currency exposure. First, hedge the currency by borrowing yen at 0.25% to buy dollars at 5.25%, for an effective yield of 5%. The bond-futures contract you buy with those funds effectively yields about 1.25% to 1.5%, or the difference between the underlying bond's 1.5%-to-1.75% yield and the 0.25% yield on short-term Japanese bonds.]   By buying JGB futures you are increasing your spread, though at the risk of the Japanese economy strengthening and the Bank of Japan raising interest rates either gradually or substantially over time. If you buy a junk bond in the U.S. you are risking default. If you buy a JGB future you are risking future yield in terms of an overnight raid by the Bank of Japan.   Gabelli: You don't think they will raise rates in the next few weeks?   Gross: I do. I think they'll go to 50 basis points, but there they'll stop, because with oil prices falling, the Japanese economy nominally will be sinking below the line again. [The BOJ voted Thursday to leave rates unchanged at 0.25%.] If they stop at 0.50%, you'll not only get the yield from this contract, but some appreciation, as well.     Barron's: Japan's fiscal situation is worse than ours.   Gross: They have a lot of debt from the standpoint of their federal deficit, which they are trying to correct. In terms of their dollar reserves, however, they are one of the wealthiest countries in the world. Though they have internal deficits of substantial magnitude, they have been saving lots of money. So the economy is not as bad as it would appear.   Zulauf: Bill, are you assuming Japanese policymakers are making a mistake in being too tight, and that the economy will sink again?   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: UK PRESS:Jurys Doyle Weighs Possible Sale Of Hotel Brand
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--Dublin-based Jurys Doyle Hotel Group PLC  has hired advisers to look at a possible sale of its Jurys Inn brand worth up to EUR1 billion, the Times of London reported Saturday, without quoting sources. The three-star brand has 20 hotels, of which 14 are in Britain and six in Ireland.   The company, taken private at the end of 2005, has appointed Merrill Lynch to consider a number of options for Jurys Inn including splitting its underlying property assets from the operating arm, the Times reported. However, an outright sale of the brand is understood by the Times to be the likeliest outcome. According to the Times, with two-thirds of the Jurys Inns being freehold properties, the auction is likely to attract wide interest from trade rivals, private equity firms and property investors.   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9320     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 06:29 ET (11:29 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: India ICICI Bank 3Q Net INR9.10 Bln Vs INR6.40 Bln
Story: MUMBAI (Dow Jones)--India's ICICI Bank Ltd. (532174.BY) Saturday posted a 42.2% on-year rise in fiscal third-quarter net profit, boosted by strong growth in interest income.   Net profit for the quarter ended Dec. 31, 2006, rose to INR9.10 billion ($205.5 million), from INR6.40 billion a year earlier, beating expectations. The averaged estimates from a Dow Jones Newswires poll of six analysts forecast a net profit of INR8.16 billion.   The New York-listed bank, India's largest in the private sector in terms of deposits, said total income in the quarter jumped 59.5% on-year to INR78.05 billion from INR48.92 billion.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  January 20, 2007 02:34 ET (07:34 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
